President Ashraf Ghani participated, along with officials from the Health Ministry and elsewhere.  In this first round, Afghan security force members, journalists and doctors received the vaccine.   The first stage of the vaccination in Afghanistan will start with 500,000 doses, President Ghani said at the event, adding that "efforts are underway to cover 40 percent of the population in the second round."   Recently, Afghanistan received 500,000 doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine from India. The vaccines were produced by the Serum Institute of India. "

Vaccinating journalists does not fit the given A/B/C rubric: "A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), C- Elderly groups"    https://archive.vn/ZVaje#selection-423.0-426.0  "Kabul, Afghanistan, 16 March 2021 – **Teachers in schools and universities set to receive the COVAX COVID-19 vaccine**   Today, ahead of schools re-opening on 21 March, the Ministry of Public Health has prioritized teachers to receive the COVID-19 vaccine so that schools stay open, teachers stay safe and children keep learning.    COVAX – a coalition of partners including the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), Gavi, the Vaccine Aliance, UNICEF and WHO – was created to ensure that as COVID-19 vaccines are rolled out around the world, the process is done fairly so that all countries, especially the poorest, receive vaccines and are better able to protect their most vulnerable populations.   COVAX has shipped 468 000 doses of the COVISHIELD vaccine from the AstraZeneca Serum Institute of India, in Mumbai to Afghanistan. The delivery is part of a first wave of arrivals that will continue in the coming weeks and months."

Angola received it's first batch of vaccines from COVAX on the 4th of March and has already jabbed 90 plus people. It's stated priority groups are as follows: health professionals, teachers, defense and security forces, and people with comorbidities. I've coded all of these individuals as three groups: the healthcare force, the "essential" workforce meaning teachers, defense services, and thirdly, those with co-morbidities.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307204010/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/vacinados-primeiros-cidadaos-contra-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307204352/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/angola-preve-imunizar-mais-de-16-milhoes-de-pessoas/

Angola received it's first batch of vaccines from COVAX on the 4th of March and on the same day  a group of 92 people were vaccinated.   Priority groups include: health professionals, teachers, defence and security forces, and people with comorbidities.  In addition to the first batch of vaccines under the COVAX initiative, Angola received vaccines from the AstraZeneca company, of Indian origin, which will supply 12.8 million doses by the end of July.  https:/web/20210313223557/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/vacinados-primeiros-cidadaos-contra-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210313223826/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/angola-preve-imunizar-mais-de-16-milhoes-de-pessoas/

The first doses of the SARS-CoV-2 Coronavirus vaccine arrived in Andorra on Tuesday evening. These are 1,000 units of the Pfizer vaccine from Madrid, to which will be added 1,000 more - those corresponding to the second dose of vaccination to be administered - over the next few days.  As stated by the Minister of Health, Joan Martínez Benazet, phase 1 of the vaccination campaign will begin tomorrow (Jan 20, 2021). Thus, the first vaccinated will be users of health centers and health professionals. This first vaccination round will last for two weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126110307/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12342-arriben-les-primeres-dosis-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-coronavirus

A,C:  The Minister of Health has announced the start of vaccination against COVID-19, which took place this morning in different parts of the country. The vaccination is currently aimed at residents of health centers and health professionals. The ministry believes that the administration of this first consignment will last approximately two weeks. Finally, the minister explained that in addition to the 1,000 doses received yesterday (Jan 19, 2021), 1,000 more will be added this week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126111139/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12348-administrades-les-primeres-200-dosis-de-la-vacuna-a-residents-de-centres-sociosanitaris-i-professionals-de-la-salut

A,C:  This Thursday (Jan 21, 2021), a new consignment arrived in the country with 1,000 more vaccines that will be used to administer the second dose to the first thousand people and thus achieve immunity against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126112624/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12350-andorra-s-aprovisiona-de-la-vacuna-contra-la-covid-19-seguint-els-criteris-i-mecanismes-establerts-a-europa

A & C. Andorra is implementing its vaccination campaign using the Pfizer vaccine. The vaccines have been administered to healthcare and social healthcare workers from various fields as well as the residents of the social healthcare homes which have not been recently affected by the virus. Starting February 7, a nationwide decision by the Ministry of Health, which said all vaccine centres were now dedicated "only to the elderly and people with chronic diseases, in the light of the spike in infections over the past weeks...But people who have not yet had their first dose are expected to wait until next month. Walk-in services will end and younger people will be seen by appointment only."   "Four vaccines are available in the UAE. The Sinopharm and Sputnik V drugs are available across the UAE, although the latter is only for emergency use.  Pfizer-BioNTech and Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines are available in Dubai. Currently, specific priority groups are being vaccinated in Dubai, with plans for a wider programme later in the year."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207152420/https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/health/abu-dhabi-limits-vaccines-to-elderly-and-disabled-for-next-six-weeks-1.1161411

Vaccines will be administered to the following people on priority. They are eligible to walk into most vaccination centres and clinics without an appointment:  UAE nationals and their household workers  Senior citizens and residents (those who are 60 years old and above). -C  People of determination  People with chronic illnesses B  Those working in the health and education centres. ABU DHABI, 20th March, 2021 (WAM) -- The Ministry of Health and Prevention has urged all Emiratis and residents eligible for COVID-19 vaccination to start booking appointments for inoculation starting Sunday, March 21, now that the six-week priority entitlement given to people who are most at risk of infection is over.    Those eligible for vaccination, including citizens and residents aged 16 and above, can now get inoculated for free in any of the 205 vaccination locations available nationwide, the ministry said in a statement tonight.    The statement said it's incumbent on those opting for vaccination to get prior booking as those who are most vulnerable to infection will continue to be received by vaccination centres without prior booking.    The past six weeks saw a collaborative effort made by all health departments to prioritise those most at risk of infection, including the elderly and people with chronic diseases, such as heart, diabetes, and respiratory illnesses.    In the meantime, Dr. Abdul Rahman bin Mohammad bin Nasser Al Owais, Minister of Health and Prevention, said Saturday that 72.89 percent of elderly Emiratis and residents and those with chronic diseases have been vaccinated against COVID-19 and that 56.59 percent of the eligible population have been inoculated against the disease.    In line with the Ministry's plans as well as the objectives of the National COVID-19 Vaccination Campaign, to ensure acquired community immunity, the Ministry has urged all the eligible population to get vaccinated and to encourage their family members, friends and colleagues to follow suit for their common good.    The UAE has approved four Covid vaccines for emergency uses: Sinopharm; Pfizer-BioNTech; Sputnik V; and Oxford-AstraZeneca. In addition, MoHAP is constantly working to get the entire UAE population vaccinated as soon as possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322152304/http://wam.ae/en/details/1395302920029
no change
No change in policy since previous period:     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210410220623/https://covid19.ncema.gov.ae/en

A:    Argentines will be vaccinated with the Russian Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine beginning on Tuesday 29 December.    "The doses of the Sputnik V vaccine that arrived from Russia will be available in each province and on Tuesday Dec. 29 at 9 am the simultaneous vaccination will begin throughout the country," President Alberto Fernandez said Sunday in a tweet.    Argentine medical workers began receiving the vaccine and officials insisted it was safe. President Alberto Fernández called it the largest vaccination campaign in the country’s modern history.    The vaccine  will be free and voluntary.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125537/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/argentina-covid-19-vaccinations-with-sputnik-v-start/2090879    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0

"It should be noted that the vaccines are provided by the National State and the vaccination plan is carried out in stages, free of charge, voluntarily and regardless of the history of having suffered from coronavirus."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111182006/https://www.argentina.gob.ar/noticias/ya-se-aplicaron-107542-dosis-de-la-vacuna-contra-covid-19-en-el-pais

"Australia’s pharmaceutical regulator said on Thursday it is on course to review Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine by January 2021, with the country sticking to a March timetable to start vaccinations."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201222234531if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-australia/australia-aims-to-complete-review-of-pfizers-covid-19-vaccine-by-january-2021-idUKKBN28C3EF

In the Prime Minister's announcement on 7 January 2021, he said "After considerable effort, including with our vaccine suppliers, we are now in a position where we believe we'll be able to commence vaccinations of high priority groups in mid to late February."    https://www.pm.gov.au/media/press-conference-australian-parliament-house-12

The Australian Government does have a COVID-19 Vaccination Policy published 13 November 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20210113095811/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/12/australian-covid-19-vaccination-policy.pdf     The Australian Government also has entered into 4 separate agreements for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines, if they are proved to be safe and effective. The Australian Government has invested more than $3.3 billion through these 4 agreements, which will strengthen Australia's position to access safe and effective vaccines when they become available.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102055658/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/about-covid-19-vaccines/australias-vaccine-agreements    However, this item is coded 0 because  vaccines are not yet being being administered in Australia.

The Pfizer vaccine has met strict standards for safety, quality and efficacy, a statement from the prime minister’s office said on Monday, and the vaccine has been approved for rollout in Australia for people aged 16 years and older.    The first vaccinations are expected to be in late February and the first 1.4m doses of Pfizer and other vaccines once they are available will go to a priority group that includes quarantine and border workers, frontline health workers in high-risk settings, and aged care and disability staff and residents.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210125035042/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/jan/25/pfizer-covid-vaccine-approved-for-australia-rollout-but-pm-warns-jabs-not-a-silver-bullet
Vaccines yet to rollout as of Jan 30   https://web.archive.org/web/20210131215546/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/jan/30/australias-covid-vaccine-rollout-everything-you-need-to-know

Scott Morrison, Australian Prime Minister, announce in a Media Release dated 21st Feb 2021 that "Aged care residents, nurses and doctors, disabled support residents and hotel quarantine workers, were among the first Australians to receive a COVID-19 vaccine today in Castle Hill, New South Wales.  They were joined by personnel from the Australian Defence Force and Australian Border Force alongside Australia’s Chief Medical Officer, Chief Nursing and Midwifery Officer and the Prime Minister in getting vaccinated.  The COVID-19 vaccination program was officially launched today ahead of the formal national rollout across Australia on Monday."    Australia is currently vaccinating:   Quarantine and border workers  frontline staff in facilities or services such as hospital emergency departments,COVID-19 and respiratory wards, Intensive Care Units and High-dependency Units laboratory staff handling potentially infectious material ambulance and paramedics service GP respiratory clinics, and    COVID-19 testing facilities. Currently, as at 12 March 2021, Australia remains at in phase 1a of the COVIC-19 Vaccination delivery strategy.  The following groups are receiving the vaccine: Quarantine, border and [COVID-19] front line health care workers; Aged care and disability care staff; and Aged care and disability care residents. The Hon Greg Hunt MP Minister for Health and Aged Care announced in a media release on 22nd March 2021 that "Today is a momentous day for Australia’s fight against COVID-19, with the rollout of Phase 1B of the Australian Government’s vaccination plan." ...  "Priority groups in Phase 1B include:    elderly adults aged 80 years and over  elderly adults aged 70 years and over  health care workers not vaccinated in Phase 1A  Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55  adults with a specified medical condition  adults with a severe disability who have a specified underlying medical condition  critical and high risk workers including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing."  The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia.    Both the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine and the Oxford/Astrazeneca vaccine are in use for phase 1B.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090223/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/phase-1b-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-begins   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090708/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090821/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/which-covid-19-vaccine-will-i-receive

The Hon Greg Hunt MP Minister for Health and Aged Care announced in a media release on 22nd March 2021 that "Today is a momentous day for Australia’s fight against COVID-19, with the rollout of Phase 1B of the Australian Government’s vaccination plan." ...  "Priority groups in Phase 1B include:    elderly adults aged 80 years and over  elderly adults aged 70 years and over  health care workers not vaccinated in Phase 1A  Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55  adults with a specified medical condition  adults with a severe disability who have a specified underlying medical condition  critical and high risk workers including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing."  The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia.    Both the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine and the Oxford/Astrazeneca vaccine are in use for phase 1B.  However, as documented directly below in the later part of this note.  The Australian Government announced on the 8th if April that Astrazeneca is now not the preferred vaccine for people under 50 years.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090223/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/phase-1b-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-begins   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090708/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090821/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/which-covid-19-vaccine-will-i-receive     Australia remains at Phase 1B of the Vaccine role out.  However, the Australian Government announced yesterday 8th April that they would be reviewing the COVID-19 vaccination program rollout.  This review has been prompted by updated advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group  about the AstraZeneca vaccine in response to new vaccine safety concerns.    "ATAGI recommends that the COVID-19 vaccine by Pfizer is preferred over COVID-19 Vaccine AstraZeneca in adults aged under 50 years. This recommendation is based on the increasing risk of severe outcomes from COVID-19 in older adults (and hence a higher benefit from vaccination) and a potentially increased risk of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia following AstraZeneca vaccine in those under 50 years. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409010631/https://www.health.gov.au/news/atagi-statement-on-astrazeneca-vaccine-in-response-to-new-vaccine-safety-concerns   https://web.archive.org/web/20210409054831/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine

As of 19 December, there is no COVID-19 vaccine available in Austria.    There will be free vaccines for all people in Austria who want to be vaccinated. The republic will buy the vaccines centrally and distribute them to many places, which will then carry out the vaccinations.    The federal government and other government representatives have repeatedly emphasized that there will be no general compulsory vaccination.    The first effective, safe and effective vaccines in relevant quantities could be available in Austria from the beginning of 2021. The crucial point is the central European approval for the European Union. Only then will the vaccines meet the statutory quality requirements.    Because not enough vaccines will be initially available to vaccinate everyone at the same time, the people who are at the highest risk will be vaccinated at the beginning. After that all others can be vaccinated step by step.     “We are confident that by the 2nd quarter there will be enough vaccines available to vaccinate anyone who wishes to be vaccinated.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220054442/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Haeufig-gestellte-Fragen/FAQ--COVID-19-Impfung.html

C:    On 21 December 2020, the EMA issued a positive opinion on the biontech/Pfizer vaccine and it was subsequently approved by the European Commission. On 28 December, this vaccine was administered for the first time in 3 Belgian residential care centres (located in Puurs, Brussels and Mons). From 5 January, this vaccination will be rolled out in all residential care centres. Currently, vaccines from two other companies, Moderna and Astra Zeneca/Oxford, are also undergoing the strict control of the EMA. The Moderna vaccine will be reviewed on 6 January 2021. If successful, the European Commission can give its final approval and green light for the use of this vaccine. Other potential vaccines will be examined later, including those from Johnson & Johnson or Curevac.      Will the vaccine be available to everyone from the start?  No. The vaccines will be produced continuously and quantity available will increase as they are delivered. Pending their large-scale production, several steps should be planned to best protect the most vulnerable groups and gradually increase individual immunity. (see question “Who are the priority groups?")  At the moment, it is difficult to provide a precise schedule for the administration of these vaccines. Therefore, monitoring the progressive availability of the vaccine per priority group is crucial.    To increase the population’s immunity and to protect those most vulnerable from the virus, vaccination will take place in three phases, depending on the number of doses available.    GROUP 1a    First, the most vulnerable and exposed people will be vaccinated.    Residents and employees of residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit elderly people hard, especially those living in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, followed by the staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  The medical staff from primary care and hospitals: they are in close contact with patients with Covid-19 on a daily basis. To protect them, they are vaccinated as a matter of priority.  Next, the other staff in hospitals and health services will be vaccinated, including organisations responsible for prevention activities, such as vaccination and cancer screening centres, ONE and Kind en Gezin.  In this first phase, this will require a special organisation and infrastructure (extremely low storage temperatures, multiple doses, etc.).    GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical problems but at high risk    In this phase it is expected that vaccines will become more widely available. It will then be possible to vaccinate larger groups of people. Priority will be given to people outside the hospital who are most at risk. These are the following groups:    People over 65: people over 65 are the first priority at this stage. If sufficient vaccine is available, all these people can be vaccinated at the same time. Otherwise we start with the oldest people and then work our way down.  People between 45-65 years of age with an increased risk: Then people between 45-65 years come with risk factors, such as:  Diabetes,  Hypertension, Chronic cardiovascular, pulmonary, kidney and liver disorders, haematological cancers up to 5 years after diagnosis,  All recent cancers (or recent cancer treatments)  Obesity (Body Mass Index = 30).  This list will be updated and expanded in the light of scientific developments,    Essential professions: In this phase, people with essential social and/or economic professions are vaccinated. In this second phase, we can expect fewer logistical bottlenecks and organising the vaccination will be easier for these target groups.  GROUP 2 - general population    Thirdly, vaccine doses will be available in sufficient quantities to vaccinate the rest of the population.    At this stage it can be expected that the doses can be stored and administered like other vaccines such as the flu vaccine).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165454/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/    Note: Belgium was criticised for being slow off the mark with vaccinations:  About 700 residents and staff of care homes have gotten their first shot as of January 2, when the government provided its latest update on the tally. In Germany, by contrast, roughly 317,000 doses have been administered, and about 182,000 in Italy. Yves Van Laethem, an infectious diseases specialist and spokesman for Belgium's COVID-19 crisis center, said the country is also getting fewer doses than initially promised by Pfizer — only 320,000 instead of 600,000 by late December — forcing the government to make a choice between healthcare workers and the elderly. They said they would prioritise the elderly. Hence only one group have been vaccinated in this early stage.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107121941/https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-government-criticism-coronavirus-vaccine-campaign-frank-vandenbroucke/    Other notes:  Belgium received its first batch of 9,750 vaccines last Saturday (Dec 26, 2020) and began vaccinating  between 300 and 400 people today.     Residents and staff of care homes and health care professionals will be the first to be vaccinated. Vaccinations started in three care homes across Belgium (Woluwe-Saint-Pierre in Brussels, Mons in Wallonia and Puurs in Flanders, where the BioNTech/Pfizer vaccine was produced).    Under the second phase of the plan, people over 65, patients between 45 and 65 years old at high risk from the virus due to obesity or lung disease, and people with essential jobs will get their shot. Finally, other at-risk patients and the rest of the adult population will be vaccinated.    The timing of the different phases will depend on how many doses are available at different times, and how difficult it is to store the vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165332/https://www.euronews.com/2020/12/28/covid-vaccine-man-96-is-first-to-receive-coronavirus-jab-in-belgium  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165542/https://www.politico.eu/article/what-you-need-to-know-about-belgiums-vaccination-strategy/

The government announced it is updating its Covid-19 vaccination roll-out plan which has been widely criticized for being slow. Only 700 doses were used, out of the 10,000+ vaccine doses delivered on December 28, 2020.     Professor Corinne Vandermeulen, a professor at the KU Leuven Vaccinology Department says, "we're doing the best we can. And of course there can be critics and I know that people criticize the fact that we choose to vaccinate the people in the long term care facilities first and that we might have started with healthcare workers maybe first instead of the elderly. But the elderly, they are the most vulnerable."    By the start of this week, only 700 of the over 10 thousand vaccine doses delivered to Belgium by an EU scheme on December 28th had been put into people's arms.    The only jab approved in the EU so far is the one from Pfizer-BioNtech.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107181631/https://www.euronews.com/2021/01/06/belgium-to-launch-new-coronavirus-vaccine-strategy-amid-criticism-for-a-slow-roll-out

One year after the start of the pandemic in Benin, the COVAX initiative shipped 144,000 doses of the AstraZeneca / Oxford vaccine, licensed by the Serum Institute in India, to Cotonou on March 10, 2021.    This delivery is the first batch received by Benin thanks to the COVAX facility which aims to support the Government's efforts and ensure fair and equitable access to COVID-19 vaccination. In total, 792,000 doses of vaccines will be delivered to Benin through the COVAX initiative by May 2021.    The 144,000 initial doses of vaccines were received at Cardinal Bernadin Gantin International Airport by Minister of Health Benjamin Hounkpatin and members of the COVAX initiative, namely the UNICEF Representative and the WHO Representative, accompanied by the Resident Coordinator of the United Nations System in Benin.    Benin thus joins the list of African countries that have received their first doses of COVID-19 vaccine via the COVAX mechanism. This arrival constitutes a major step forward for Benin in its fight against the COVID-19 pandemic and a historic moment towards the objective of ensuring an equitable distribution of COVID-19 vaccines throughout the world, within the framework of what constitutes the largest vaccine purchase and supply operation in history.    “Benin is very happy to receive its first vaccines against COVID-19 through the COVAX initiative. Receipt of vaccines marks a turning point in the national response to the pandemic. We are confident that with these vaccines our efforts to protect the population against the virus will be strengthened. However, we must increase awareness so that communities continue to respect barrier gestures, even after the introduction of the vaccine, ”said Minister of Health Benjamin Hounkpatin.    “These vaccines from the COVAX initiative are the result of multilateralism and international cooperation aimed at making the COVID-19 vaccine a global public good. An important step remains to be taken, that of mobilizing the population for vaccination. I would therefore like to reiterate the commitment of the United Nations to support the Government to vaccinate as many people as possible as quickly as possible, so that no one is left behind, ”said the Resident Coordinator of the United Nations System in Benin Salvator Niyonzima .    “Vaccination saves lives every year by protecting children from serious illness. With the arrival of vaccines against COVID-19, it is a ray of hope that looms on the horizon because, among the targets to be vaccinated as a priority are those that ensure the right to health and protection for each child. Our thanks also go to all our donor partners who support us on a daily basis in this initiative, ”said UNICEF Representative Djanabou Mahondé.    According to Dr Mamoudou Harouna Djingarey, Acting Resident Representative of WHO, “WHO is delighted with the successful outcome of the negotiations and agreements that have taken place between the various United Nations agencies and international and national partners to provide States with that of Benin, the quantity of vaccines needed to save human lives against COVID-19. This is a historic step in solidarity and the race towards equitable access to anti-COVID-19 vaccines for low-income countries as advocated by the COVAX initiative which is to ensure an equitable distribution of global COVID-19 vaccines ”.    “This is the most ambitious pandemic response initiative in history, and we see an important milestone in our joint efforts now that Benin and other countries in Africa begin to roll out vaccines for their most vulnerable populations, ”said Dr Antoinette Eya Awaga, Country Manager of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. "To ensure that the pandemic is behind us, we must maintain a sense of urgency and a spirit of partnership so that countries' immunization campaigns are successful, health systems recover and livelihoods be restored ”.    The vaccines transported to Benin with the support of UNICEF come from India. This first batch of vaccines will be administered to 70,000 front-line health workers and the most vulnerable, such as people over the age of 60 and people with co-morbidities. In total, 20% of the population is expected to benefit from COVAX vaccines.    A shipment of 145,000 syringes and 1,450 safety boxes, from a Gavi-funded stock from UNICEF's regional supply center in Dubai, was received on March 7, 2021.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322085142/https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/1208/    Also, Benin received this Sunday, March 21, 2021, 203,000 doses of the anticovid vaccine Coronavac from the Manufacturer SINOVAC, the result of Sino-Benin cooperation. On 4 December, the National Plan for Vaccination against COVID-19 was adopted. No deliveries yet received so coded as 0    The vaccine for Bulgarian citizens will be completely free and voluntary, according to the Prime Minister.     There are two conditions for immunization - expressed desire and informed consent.    "We are fulfilling our commitment and adopting the National Plan on time. The country is ready and logistically to meet the first delivery of vaccines and, without wasting any time, to start immunization, which will be completely free and voluntary," said Borissov.    The Minister of Health reports that the necessary freezers for storing the vaccines are already available, as well as specialized transport for their delivery in the country. Angelov emphasized that the vaccination plan specifies the phases that determine which groups of the population and in what order will be immunized against the new virus - medical teams, social and pedagogical staff, the elderly over 65 years, patients with chronic diseases."    Parliament has backed the government plan to take part in an EU scheme and get vaccine shots from Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Sanofi.    Vaccines will be administered only with the permission of the European regulator. To ensure that sufficient quantities of COVID-19 vaccines are provided in the country as soon as possible, they will be delivered centrally through a joint EU public procurement mechanism.    The government expects to receive 12-13 million doses at a total cost of about EUR 250 million (USD 304 million).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214235545/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/938    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214235756/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/939    https://web.archive.org/web/20201215015622if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-bulgaria-vaccines/bulgaria-prepares-for-covid-19-vaccines-as-death-rates-spike-idUSKBN28E0Z3

A:    The immunization of the second and third phases of the National Vaccination Plan against COVID-19 will be carried out in parallel. The members of the Central Election Commission, the district and section commissions, with which the third phase of the plan has started, will be offered the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine. This ensures that the immunization is completed with two doses of the vaccine, so that those involved in the election can be maximally protected from the virus by election day. The overlap of the phases allows Bulgarian journalists, cameramen and photojournalists to be immunized in the third phase of the Plan.     The third phase will continue with employees of Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant, water supply and sewage companies employed in the transport and communications sectors, and police officers working on the first line.    Vaccination of vulnerable groups remains a top priority for the Ministry of Health. Therefore, the end of the third phase of the National Vaccination Plan will be covered by the beginning of the fourth. In this phase, those covered by immunization will be "Elderly people over 65 years of age and those with concomitant chronic diseases, due to the more severe course of the disease and the higher risk of complications and death, including immunocompromised or persons with secondary immune deficiencies."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    More than 5,000 teachers and support staff in Sofia have expressed a desire to be immunized against COVID-19. This is a little over 20% of the pedagogical and non-pedagogical staff in the kindergartens and schools in the municipality of Sofia. Vaccination began on February 1, and more than 160 people were immunized in just one day.     The Sofia Regional Health Inspectorate has so far received about 30,000 doses of Pfizer / BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, informed the director of SRHI, Dr. Dancho Penchev. He explained that the first phase of the National Vaccination Plan is coming to an end in the capital, which includes the medical staff of outpatient and inpatient care facilities, medical specialists in health care, dentists, pharmacists, assistant pharmacists and other support staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209070608/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1263

All delivered quantities of AstraZeneca vaccine to be used for the first dose, decided today at its regular meeting the Council of the National Vaccination Headquarters. In this way, larger groups of the population will be covered and the immunization process will be accelerated.    The staff will recommend that medical professionals administer the second dose of the vaccine ten weeks after the first, according to the possibilities provided by the summary of product characteristics.    The members of the vaccination headquarters expressed the opinion that the Oxford vaccine can be used for vaccination of all Bulgarian citizens aged 18 and over.    It became clear at the meeting that the delivery of the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine was postponed due to bad weather conditions, and is expected to arrive in Bulgaria in the middle of the week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    Vaccines for all those wishing to participate in the election process are provided, Angelov was adamant. The Ministry of Health has sent a letter to the CEC requesting a list of names and contact details of the people to be immunized. The aim is to create an organization that ensures the safe conduct of parliamentary elections.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211230615/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1297

On 12 March, executive director Bogdan Kirilov issued an order which temporarily suspended immunizations with the AstraZeneca vaccine.     The order is in connection with the information received in the period 8-12 March about the occurrence of unacceptable side effects with proper use of the vaccine and the ongoing inspection of the European Medicines Agency.    AstraZeneca vaccines will remain blocked until circumstances are established and recommendations are received from the EMA's Pharmacovigilance Committee.      Also on 12 March, registration on the electronic COVID-19 vaccination portal was suspended. This was due to the temporary suspension of the AstraZeneca vaccine.     Users registered in the portal will automatically receive a new immunization hour, after analyzing the number of people registered for vaccination and the availability of the other two vaccines against COVID-19 approved in our country.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172006/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1508    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315172518/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1511

On January 9th, EyeWitness News reported that “Minister of Health Renward Wells said the government is “working on all fronts” to secure COVID-19 vaccines and expects to obtain a vaccine in-country by the second quarter of 2021.”  “COVID-19 vaccines have arrived in the British Caribbean, including the Cayman Islands and Turks and Caicos.”  “Those countries in the Caribbean [which] are receiving COVID-19 vaccines, you would realize that they are all British protectorates, a part of the United Kingdom and a part of the UK’s policy is it is distributing vaccines to its territories,” Wells said during a Ministry of Health press conference.”   “As I would have said in my statement earlier, The Bahamas government is aggressively seeking to procure vaccines and we’re doing all that we can to ensure that in the first quarter of this year that we’ll be able to present a viable vaccine to the Bahamian people.”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111210547/https://ewnews.com/covid-vaccine-within-quarter-of-2021

A COVID-19 vaccine will be available in the Bahamas in the first quarter of 2021, Chief Medical Officer Dr Pearl McMillan assured during a press conference on Friday.   However, health officials could not give a definitive timeline for a vaccine’s arrival or significant details about the vaccination protocol.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210118095656/http://www.tribune242.com/news/2021/jan/08/covid-19-vaccine-available-bahamas-first-quarter-2/

No vaccine available, however, Belarus will start administering the Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine to its citizens in January, Healthcare Minister Dmitry Pinevich told reporters on the 21st of December:    “The first batch of the vaccine will arrive in January. We will start the vaccination program in January,” Dmitry Pinevich said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228100851/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/belarus-to-start-covid-vaccinations-in-january-136062-2020/

“A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0    "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. Bermuda has two sources for procuring vaccines against COVID-19.  Bermuda will be supplied with 9,000 doses of the Pfizer vaccine and they will arrive on our shores in the first week of January 2021.   The second vaccine source is through Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance Geneva, which is administering the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility (the “COVAX Facility”). Bermuda has joined the COVAX Facility, and has purchased enough doses to cover 20% of our population. The leading vaccines likely to be received by Bermuda are those by AstraZeneca and Moderna. The timeframe for receipt of these vaccines through the COVAX Facility is not yet settled.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201215000755/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-vaccine-bermuda

On the 8th of January, the first shipment for 9,750 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine arrived, on the British Airways flight. The UK has provided these 9,750 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine and equipment free of charge in order to support Bermuda’s public health and economic objectives. https://archive.vn/VKXPo     For more information on the COVID-19 vaccination programme. Brunei has not started vaccinations, however, there has been new developments with regards to this:    As reported by the Borneo Bulletin on 6 March (https://archive.ph/ztw24), Brunei has outlined a vaccination strategy in three phases.    "Brunei’s citizens and residents, including foreign nationals with a valid IC, will receive the COVID-19 vaccination for free. The vaccination process will be in place once the COVID-19 vaccine arrives in the country.    Details about the COVID-19 vaccination were revealed on the Brunei Darussalam Vaccination Strategy, Ministry of Health website. The vaccine distribution is divided into three phases.    Phase one is for frontliners, senior citizens aged 60 and above and students who will be studying overseas. Phase two is for the staff at childcare centres, adults at high risk and teachers, while phase three is for the public aged 18 and above.    Four locations have been identified for the inoculation of the vaccine. They are the Indoor Stadium in Brunei-Muara District, Pengiran Muda Mahkota Pengiran Muda Haji Al-Muhtadee Billah (PMMPMHAMB) Hospital in Tutong District, Suri Seri Begawan Hospital in Belait District and Pengiran Isteri Hajjah Mariam Hospital in Temburong District.    Bookings can be done through the BruHealth app by verifying the BruHealth account and clicking on the COVID-19 vaccination slot. Individuals must read the COVID-19 vaccination participation information statement and fill the questionnaires, according to the website."    Additionally, the Bruneian Minister of Health Dato Seri Setia Dr Haji Mohd Isham bin Haji Jaafar announced on 6 March that the first COVAX vaccine (vaccine type unknown), will arrive in Brunei 'sometime this month [March]'.    See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the Vaccination Strategy, archived at https://archive.ph/ztw24  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the Minister of Health's comments on COVAX, archived at https://archive.ph/ZGx72  See the Ministry of Health's newly-released Vaccination Strategy Report, in Malay, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/7ltgnilgurhqtuv/BRN-20210306-MOH-StrategiVaksinasiNegaraBruneiDarussalam.pdf

Brunei has not started vaccinations, however, there have been 5 vaccine candidates that have been identified for Brunei, according to the Borneo Bulletin reported on 12 March (owned by the government of Brunei; reported in Xinhua)    "According to local daily the Borneo Bulletin on Friday, the five candidates for Brunei people are vaccines from Pfizer BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca, China's Sinopharm, and Johnson and Johnson, respectively. The country's vaccination strategy will be implemented once the vaccines arrive in the country."    As noted in previous notes, Brunei previously received its first shipment of Covid-19 vaccines (Sinopharm) from China on 09 February; and revealed its vaccination strategy on 06 March. As per the 06 March note, the country also expects to receive its first shipment of Covid-19 vaccines procured from the COVAX facility by the end of March.    See Xinhua's news report, archived at https://archive.ph/FLCv2

Vaccinations have still not started in Brunei.    There has been further progress in the logistics end for Brunei's vaccination. As per the Borneo Bulletin, reported on 23rd March, "Four locations for the administration of the vaccine have been selected: Indoor Stadium in Brunei-Muara District; Pengiran Muda Mahkota Pengiran Muda Haji Al-Muhtadee Billah Hospital in Tutong District; Suri Seri Begawan Hospital in Belait District; and Pengiran Isteri Hajjah Mariam Hospital in Temburong District." TLDR: Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, procured via the COVAX facility, arrived on Brunei on the morning of the 2nd. Vaccination will commence the next day, on the 3rd.    "On 31st March 2021, COVAX shipped 24,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine, from Amsterdam via Singapore to Brunei Darussalam, arriving on the morning of 02 April 2021. These 24,000 doses are the first of a total of 100,800 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine expected to be provided in batches by the COVAX Facility by the end of June."    See the WHO press release, archived at https://archive.vn/gTsEW  See the Ministry of Health press release, archived athttps://archive.vn/TlsgY

A:    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    Following yesterday's (2nd April) joint WHO-Brunei press release that Brunei has received 24,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine via the COVAX facility, Brunei has started vaccination, where "vaccine shots will be given to around 2,000 local frontliners, including health facility staff, uniformed personnel from the Royal Brunei Armed Forces, Royal Brunei Police Force, as well as those involved in quarantines and immigration post control affairs [in the first phase]".    According to the Bruneian Minister of Health, Haji Awang Mohammad Isham, the ministry "deployed Sinopharm and AstraZeneca vaccines for the first day of the national vaccination program in the country". The Sultan of Brunei has also taken his first dose of the vaccine (although not specified which), and "has consented for the rolling-out of the national vaccination program".    The morning session saw more than 340 people received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine nationwide, with the total tally at 754 by the end of the day.    According to Xinhua (https://archive.vn/P1su4), emergency use authorisation has also been given to the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine (tozinameran), which has not arrived nor been used yet.    Additionally, per the US Embassy in Brunei,    COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Brunei approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Are vaccines available in Brunei Darussalam for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes.  Which vaccines are available in Brunei Darussalam?  Oxford-AstraZeneca and Sinopharm while the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Novavax are expected at a later date.  The COVID-19 vaccine will be provided free of charge to citizens and residents residing in Brunei Darussalam.  Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for information to Brunei Darussalam Vaccination Strategy.    COVAX announcements:  See the WHO press release, archived at https://archive.vn/gTsEW  See the Ministry of Health press release, archived at https://archive.vn/TlsgY    Start of vaccination announcements/press releases:  See Ministry of Health's announcement, archived at https://archive.vn/divhM (in Malay)  See Xinhua's report, archived at https://archive.vn/Ae3w2  See the US Embassy in Brunei's page on COVID-19, archived at https://archive.vn/Zhhlx

A:    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There had been no updates as to whether the vaccinations have been administered to other groups; however, the Bruneian Ministry of Health and Ministry of Education has opened up registration for local students (Citizens of Brunei Darussalam) and foreign students who will pursue studies abroad.    According to the Ministry of Health,     "2. All students who will pursue their studies abroad must first make and update registration through the Ministry of Education by visiting the Ministry of Education website: www.moe.gov.bn or link: https://bit.ly/3qsLcdD         3. Next, the Ministry of Health has set the conditions for the students who want to follow the COVID-19 National Vaccination Program, namely:                 The administration of COVID-19 vaccine will be given on a priority basis subject to the expected dates of leaving Brunei Darussalam;                       COVID-19 vaccine will only be given to students who will be going abroad in the next one (1) month. This is to ensure they receive two doses of vaccine to get the best protection;                       Must be 18 years of age or older;                       Only given to those who have a Bru-HIMS account. For those who have not registered a Bru-HIMS account can register at a previous government clinic or hospital BEFORE making an agreement or come to a vaccination center that has been dedicated to facilitate the vaccination process;                       Vaccination is subject to the vaccination centers that have been identified. They will receive a short message service (SMS) for the date, time and location of the identified vaccination center."    See the Ministry of Health's announcement, in Malay, archived at https://archive.vn/jI3So

The first consignment of the vaccine will arrive in the country very soon.  The plan is to vaccinate all the people together, so we will roll out the nationwide vaccination program only when we have sufficient doses for all the targetted population. No availability yet, but the government has announced that it is pursuing the purchase of vaccines and is aiming for rollout by end of March.    See public advisory (https://web.archive.org/web/20210301160351/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment/status/1365364318599004166/photo/1).

Botswana has made an upfront payment to COVAX, the World Health Organization (WHO)’s vaccine arrangement, to acquire 940,800 vaccines under a two-dose regime, enough to cover about 20 percent of the population. In addition, Botswana has paid US$7.1 million to the African Vaccine Acquisition Task Team (AVATT) to secure more vaccine doses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081515/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

On 9 December, Health Canada approved Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine “for use in people 16 years of age or older”. “Canada will receive up to 249,000 doses” later this month. The federal government is arranging distribution to provincial governments with the first group of high-priority recipients expected to receive vaccinations before year end. See Government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210205358/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2020/12/health-canada-authorizes-first-covid-19-vaccine0.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210210347/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/12/canada-to-receive-early-delivery-of-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 10 December, Prime Minister Trudeau repeated the Government of Canada’s commitment that the covid-19 “vaccine would be completely free for all Canadians”. See Global News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216164929/https://globalnews.ca/news/7514966/coronavirus-canada-vaccine-rollout-trudeau/

On 14 December, Ontario began vaccinating health care workers in Toronto and Quebec vaccinated workers and residents at long-term care facilities in Montreal and Quebec City. Other provinces are expected to start targeted vaccinations of high-risk groups later this week. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216165500/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-administers-its-first-covid-19-vaccine-shots/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214190242/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-personal-support-worker-first-person-in-canada-to-receive-dose/

A, C:    On 30 December, vaccinations began in remote indigenous communities in British Columbia (BC). Members of three groups -- long-term care residents, frontline workers, remote indigenous community residents -- have now been vaccinated somewhere in Canada. Vaccinations are expected to start soon in indigenous communities in other provinces. However, to my knowledge, there is no province that has vaccinated members of more than 2 groups at this time. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website and Province of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103010814/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-vaccine-rollout-picks-up-speed-in-first-nations-across-canada/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162416/http://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/covid-19/covid-19-vaccine/bcs-plan-for-vaccine-distribution

On 14 January 2021, the Government of Quebec announced that, if vaccine supply is insufficient, the second vaccination dose will be delayed for up to 90 days in order to maximize first doses to members of high-risk groups. The Government of Canada’s Deputy Chief Public Health Officer “noted … that there is no data to support extending the interval past 42 days. However, he … suggested the ethical issues raised by a surge in cases and a resulting spike in hospitalizations and deaths could present an exceptional enough circumstance to justify it.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115140139/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-further-delaying-second-dose-of-covid-19-vaccines/

See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126030320/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

On 20 January 2021, Indigenous Services Canada announced: “The rollout of the vaccines to many First Nations, Inuit, and Métis communities has started. Vaccine administration continues within communities, thanks to the commitment of Indigenous leadership and health experts, and federal, provincial, Indigenous collaboration, including on logistics and data sharing. To date vaccination has begun in 169 communities for First Nations or Inuit in all provinces and territories except Nova Scotia and PEI.” Covid vaccinations (Pfizer and Moderna) in Canada are being administered to 3 groups -- A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or other health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126020941/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/01/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-older-at-risk-federal-inmates-to-receive-shot-sparking-criticism-from/

As of 25 January 1:05 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 733,500 Canadians [1.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 96,537 [0.25%] of Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124221629/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 29 January 10:25 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 82.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 829,385 Canadians [almost 2.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 96,857 Canadians [0.25%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” Note that previous estimates of the number of Canadians fully vaccinated were incorrect due to a data reporting error by one of the provinces. Delays in vaccine delivery to Canada have resulted in first-does vaccinations being halted in the province of Alberta. In most other provinces and territories, vaccine supply is sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129155032/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163115/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/covid-update-deena-hinshaw-alberta-1.5891450

As of today, 89.1% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 883,648 Canadians [2.3% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 150,807 Canadians [almost 0.4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has resulted in a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010943/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205162839/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/gov
