As of 19 February 11:12AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,007,878 Canadians [2.65% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 372,911 Canadians [almost 1%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past 4 weeks. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217180702/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184842/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 26 February 10:21AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,231,835 Canadians [3.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 497,318 Canadians [1.3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past month. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations are starting or are about to start for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. On 26 Feb. 2021, Health Canada authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine (including the version from the Serum Institute of India) for use in Canada for those aged 18 and up. See CTV news, Globe newspaper, and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224122201/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226155631/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-health-canada-approves-astrazenecas-covid-19-vaccine-for-people-over/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160443/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-with-a-mass-expansion-of-the-covid-19-vaccine-program-just-weeks-away/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160132/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities2.html

A,B,C: On 1 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommended against using the AstraZenec-Oxford vaccine in people aged 65 and older, although Health Canada has authorized it to be used in adults of all ages”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308155125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/astra-zeneca-vaccine-naci-age-1.5932347

A,B,C: On 3 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommends that in the context of limited COVID-19 vaccine supply, jurisdictions should maximize the number of individuals benefiting from the first dose of vaccine by extending the interval for the second dose of vaccine to four months”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans to include the four-month interval. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308154413/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/rapid-response-extended-dose-intervals-covid-19-vaccines-early-rollout-population-protection.html

A,B,C: On 5 March 2021, “Health Canada authorized the COVID-19 vaccine manufactured by Janssen Inc. [owned by Johnson & Johnson]…. for use in people over 18 years of age”. “Health Canada has now approved four distinct COVID-19 vaccines, with the others being from Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Oxford-AstraZeneca.” The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being administered to Canadians. Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines may not have been administered yet. The first shipment to Canada arrived 3rd March. See CBC news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305211028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/naci-interval-advice-change-four-months-1.5934563  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305203353/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-authorizes-janssen-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 8 March 2021 1:30PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1864745 Canadians [4.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 567,954 Canadians [almost 1.5%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations have started for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. According to Canada’s Minister of Indigenous Services, “more than 127,000 COVID-19 vaccine doses have been administered in more than 480 First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities... approximately 40% of the indigenous population in First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities having received at least one dose.”  See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308184423/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308160146/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities.html

As of 12 March 2021 12:50PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 2,205,244 Canadians [5.8% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 589,048 Canadians [1.55%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of J&J shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312175918/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312180206/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html

As of 22 March 2021 5:50PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 3,409,857 Canadians [9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 632,489 Canadians [1.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education and emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322224218/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 24 March 2021, Health Canada updated the product monograph—or label—for the AstraZeneca and COVISHIELD COVID-19 vaccines to provide information on very rare reports of blood clots associated with low levels of blood platelets (i.e., thrombocytopenia) following immunization with the AstraZeneca vaccine...The Department has also issued guidance for healthcare professionals and vaccine recipients on the potential symptoms to monitor. Health Canada reassures Canadians that the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine continues to be safe and effective at protecting them against COVID-19 and encourages people to get immunized with any of the COVID-19 vaccines that are authorized in Canada.”  See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326174902/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-issues-label-change-and-guidance-on-the-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 26 March 2021 1:05PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 4,083,225 Canadians [11% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 651,750 Canadians [1.7%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326175238/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/covid-19-vaccine-treatment/vaccine-rollout.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322224218/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 29 March 2021, Canada’s “National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) is recommending an immediate pause in the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine in all individuals less than 55 years of age in Canada. This is based on evidence of rare instances of vaccine-induced pro-thrombotic immune thrombocytopenia (VIPIT) following AstraZeneca vaccination reported in Europe”. All provinces and territories accepted this advice. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405135723/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/03/use-of-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 5 april 2021 12:09PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 5,790,687 Canadians [15% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 706,144 Canadians [2%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but shipments will not arrive until later this month. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405194500/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405133338/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities3.html

On 6 april 2021, a newspaper reported that some provinces have considered “vaccine passports” to allow greater freedom of movement. Pfizer, Moderna, and AstraZeneca continue to be vaccines in use. Janssen approved, but not yet delivered. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407223337/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-considered-digital-covid-19-vaccine-passport-plan-documents/

As of 9 april 2021 12:59PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 6,676,067 Canadians [18% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 767,421 Canadians [2%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 55+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments will not arrive until later this month. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409172502/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 19 april 2021 12:59PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 9,300,924 Canadians [24.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 919,090 Canadians [2%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 55+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments will not arrive until later this month. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419215623/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

B: Pfizer/BioNTech    First canton (Lucerne) launches vaccination campaign on December 23, starting with vulnerable residents over 65. In the first phase, individual cantons can begin the first vaccinations for people in vulnerable groups on a step-by-step basis. Vaccinations will take place in specific settings such as old people’s and care homes. Starting 4 January 2021, the vaccination of people in vulnerable groups and other priority groups will then start all over Switzerland.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102134745/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102134839/https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/first-covid-19-vaccine-approved-for-swiss-use/46234782

B,C: Pfizer/BioNTech      Vaccination was started in most cantons on 4 January 2021. Especially vulnerable people are being vaccinated first.   The following people are to be given access to vaccinations first:  * People age 75 and over  * People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109120317/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Second vaccine - Moderna - approved for use on January 12.     B;C     Targeted groups amended to explicitly identify care home/retirement home residents and staff : "The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time."     However, still coded as two groups rather than three as "key workers" are not categorically being vaccinated; rather, only some care/retirement home staff has the option of vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Recoded from 1G to 2G as official government policy allows for both B & C to access vaccine nationally, despite lags or variation in localized vaccine rollout. Not coded as 3G as "key workers" are not able to categorically access the vaccine; rather only a limited portion of care/retirement home workers have the option of vaccination.     B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    Original coding note:     Note that the federal policy is to give access first to A, B and C:    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:  ?	People age 75 and over  ?	People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  ?	People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    However, the status is that only elderly people are indeed getting shots in arms in all cantons. In some cantons B and C are vaccinated. In Zurich, A and C. In others, only C (detailed sources below). Based on the coding guidance that Geographic coverage needs to be national before this is coded, as we code the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, changing to 1G.  Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNTec, Moderna. Undergoing approval process: AstraZeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110150607/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Clinically vulnerable people under 75 now also being vaccinated as well, e.g. in Zug:  https://archive.vn/v7s4P  and Baselland:  https://archive.vn/KPry4    But the roll out varies across cantons, e.g. in Basel-city only the elderly over 75 are being invited to get vaccinated.  https://archive.vn/WVWiv  https://archive.vn/hJDAb    Similarly, in Bern, where only people over 75 years old are being vaccinated for now.  https://archive.vn/rRwCL#selection-1591.0-1595.92    In Zurich, residents and staff in elderly care home have started to receive vaccines.   https://archive.vn/cZiRN  In Tessin, elderly care home residents and staff, as well as the over 85-year-olds can book vaccinations.  https://archive.vn/T29oA    Note there are reports of a slow roll out of the vaccine program.  https://archive.vn/ukR7N

No policy changes.    B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  If you are in the group of people with chronic diseases of the highest risk, the doctor treating you will urgently recommend you to have the vaccination as soon as possible.    After that come:    People aged between 65 and 74  People under 65 and people with chronic diseases who have not yet been vaccinated  Following people at especially high risk (vulnerable people), the vaccination will also be offered to the following target groups in the corresponding order.    Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the handicapped).  It has become apparent that these priorities are being put into practice differently from canton to canton. In particular there are differences in the vaccination of healthcare professionals. For this reason the Federal Vaccination Commission (EKIF/CFV) and the FOPH have drawn up guidelines specifying which groups of healthcare professionals may possibly be vaccinated at the same time as especially vulnerable people (target group 1). Given that volumes of vaccine are currently limited, the goal is to assure the provision of healthcare in areas that are particularly affected while making sufficient vaccine available for especially vulnerable people at the highest risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205081724/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/

ABC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    "As of this Monday March 8, more than 89 thousand people with severe or profound disabilities will receive the first dose against Covid-19"    " In the vaccination calendar established by the Ministry of Health, it was specified that from March 15 people in the transport sector can be vaccinated, with which it is expected to inoculate more than 74 thousand drivers of basic taxis, executives, tourism , collectives, school transport and bus drivers. "    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162249/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/partir-de-este-lunes-mas-de-89-mil-personas-con-discapacidad-severa-o-profunda-recibiran-primera-dosis-contra-el-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162512/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/chile-recibe-209-mil-dosis-adicionales-de-la-vacuna-pfizer-biontech-y-laboratorio-cansino-solicita-autorizacion-ante-el-isp/

ABC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    "As of this Monday March 8, more than 89 thousand people with severe or profound disabilities will receive the first dose against Covid-19"    " In the vaccination calendar established by the Ministry of Health, it was specified that from March 15 people in the transport sector can be vaccinated, with which it is expected to inoculate more than 74 thousand drivers of basic taxis, executives, tourism , collectives, school transport and bus drivers. "    "« Today (March 24) a milestone is marked starting with the healthy population, under 60 years of age. We have finished (vaccinating) people who have chronic diseases, the elderly and that is important. We are starting with the 59-year-old group of the population, tomorrow those who are 58 and the next day those who are 57 years old and so we will continue until they are 50 years old. We want to ensure that this entire age range between 50 and 59 years is vaccinated before April 9, "said the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza."    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329174435/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/minsal-inicia-proceso-de-vacunacion-de-poblacion-sana/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162249/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/partir-de-este-lunes-mas-de-89-mil-personas-con-discapacidad-severa-o-profunda-recibiran-primera-dosis-contra-el-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162512/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/chile-recibe-209-mil-dosis-adicionales-de-la-vacuna-pfizer-biontech-y-laboratorio-cansino-solicita-autorizacion-ante-el-isp/

12 December    Provincial governments across China are placing orders for experimental, domestically made coronavirus vaccines, though health officials have yet to say how well they work or how they may reach the country’s 1.4 billion people.    Developers are speeding up final testing, the Chinese foreign minister said during a U.N. meeting last week    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184213/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/06/china-prepares-large-scale-rollout-of-coronavirus-vaccines-443159

This extended note aims to capture the progress on vaccination programme before it is rolled out to the entire country (does not include R&D, clinic trials).    The China National Medicine Products Administration (MPA) has not formally approved the Sinopharm Inactivated vaccine to go to the market. However, the green light is anticipated in the next few days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214212000/https://weareunited.com.my/11515744/    On 24 June 2020, the MPA approved the emergency use of COVID-19 vaccine. Voluntary vaccination started on around 17 June. The first batch of receivers consisted mainly of key workers, including state-owned enterprise employees who must go overseas to countries where the pandemic hits hard; medical staff, epidemic-control staff, border force and other essential workers who keep cities running.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231804/https://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/cyxw/2020-11-18/doc-iiznezxs2537217.shtml    From mid-October, Zhejiang province has offered vaccines to ordinary citizens on a voluntary basis. The rationale has been that many cities in Zhejiang have export-oriented economies; for example, Yiwu city is the world centre for light industry commodity trading. Many wholesale merchants were keen on receiving vaccines so that they can travel to Latin America and Africa to inspect their businesses. See BBC reports below. By mid-November, Zhejiang had provided vaccines to some 743,000 people. Voluntary vaccines were paid by recipients. Two doses cost roughly 400 CNY plus a service charge of around 56 CNY, which altogether equals to approximately 70 USD.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231741/https://www.bbc.com/zhongwen/simp/chinese-news-54628714    As the vaccination programme is yet to roll out to the whole country, there is no national policy on who will get the vaccine first. However, Sichuan province, where the most recent cluster of infection was found, did publish a detailed plan to that sets out the order:    The first group to receive vaccines consists of people facing high risks of infection, including medical staffs with International assistance mission, national health emergency rescue team in Sichuan, fever clinic and frontline doctors and nurses, border control force, frontline health inspection and epidemic-control officials, students or workers going overseas, police force, frozen food industry workers, essential workers for keeping cities running, teachers, other medical staffs, doctors and nurses, community social workers. The first batch is estimated to have 2 million people. Vaccination for them has started and will finish within 2020.    The second group to receive vaccines mainly consists of vulnerable people, including elderly people and people with chronic diseases. Vaccination for them will start from early next year (January).    The third batch will open to the general public. Ordinary people are estimated to start receiving vaccines after the Chinese New Year (12 February 2021).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214221555/https://www.sohu.com/a/437018675_114988    So far, vaccination is not and is unlike to be paid by social medical insurance funds in the future. The National Health Security Administration has cited laws and regulations as the justification that vaccination is a part of public health effort, which should be shouldered by public finance resources, rather than social medical insurance funds.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214211226/https://www.sohu.com/a/425495553_114986    UAE and Bahrain have formally approved the Sinopharm vaccine on 9th and 13th December 2020 respectively.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231619/http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-12/09/c_1126842251.htm  http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231549/http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2020-12/14/c_1126855787.htm

Vaccination policy differs across cities. For example, some cities/provinces, including Beijing and Wuhan, have started to vaccinated undergraduates since late March; in some cities/provinces, including Shanghai and Guangdong, foreign residents can make appointment for vaccination from early- and mid-April (in Guangdong, foreign residents not in the social welfare system need to pay 100RMB (c.15 USD) per jab). And in many cities, vaccines have started to roll-out to the over-60s.     https://archive.vn/DaSP3  https://archive.vn/yexnQ  https://archive.vn/3Iost  https://archive.vn/1C4q5  https://archive.vn/8VHvW    None of the news above specified which vaccine is being administered.

Vaccination policy differs across cities. A, C:    The first stage of vaccination will be for the priority population, i.e. frontline health personnel and 100% of the population over the age of 80. This comprises about 11 million people (7.6 million over the age of 60 and 1.2 million in health personnel) and would begin in January 2021.    In phase two it will focus on vaccination of 100% of the population from 60 to 79 years old and health personnel of the second and third hotlines. This comprises about 7.19 million. While in phase three, 2.95 million people will be vaccinated; phase four, 4.91 million; and in phase five, about 17.4 million.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221215935/https://www.larepublica.co/especiales/mis-documentos-2020/conozca-como-sera-el-plan-de-vacunacion-contra-el-covid-19-en-colombia-desde-enero-3104233

Publication of National Vaccine Plan, with the government committing to covering the cost of vaccines for the population:  "The following target groups for vaccination are prioritized in the first phase: Health professionals; People with chronic diseases (high blood pressure, diabetes); Population aged = 60 years; Hotel and tourism professionals; Entry point professionals (international airports and ports); Teachers and staff support in schools; National Police; Armed Forces and national Civil Protection and Fire Service."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210307185459/https://covid19.cv/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/bo_18-02-2021_19-ok.pdf

Not yet being put in arms, but the first wave of COVAX Astrazenica vaccines have been delivered, 24,000. Inoculation thought to begin March 19th.      "Cape Verde on Friday received the first batch of 24,000 COVAX COVID-19 AstraZeneca vaccines and is set to commence its inoculation programme on March 19th, hoping to reach 70% of its population later this year...The prime minister said that soon another 80,000 doses of the vaccine from the same pharmaceutical company will arrive, and on March 15, 5,850 doses of Pfizer will arrive, also under the same international mechanism.    Asked about the fact that several European countries have suspended the administration of the AstraZeneca vaccine, the Cape Verdean leader said that there is no scientific evidence of a relationship between cases of strong blood clotting and its application."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312105522/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/12/cape-verde-receives-24000-astrazeneca-vaccines/

For this first phase of vaccination, some groups of people were prioritized taking into account the risk of developing serious disease that can cause even death and professional groups that are on the front line of combating the pandemic. Thus, the priority groups to be vaccinated in this first phase are health professionals; chronic patients (hypertensive and diabetic); population over 60 years of age; hotel professionals and related to tourism; professionals from ports and airports; teachers and support staff in schools; police; armed forces; and civil protection professionals and firefighters.    So far the country has received two types of vaccines, bewith achstraZeneca and the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. Meanwhile, the country may receive other vaccines, with the support of the World Bank.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155801/https://covid19.cv/vacinas/

"""    Staff and residents at retirement or nursing homes.  First responders, including health personnel.  Costa Rica’s older population, defined here as those ages 58 and up. The vulnerable groups of the population refer to:  - Chronic pulmonary illness.  - Severe Chronic Renal Deficiency.  - Cardiac failure of any etiology (ischemic or non-etiological) stage according to  NYHA III or IV.  - Cardiovascular disease  - Congenital heart disease following surgical correction with significant residual  damage or uncorrected congenital heart disease with significant residual  damage.  - Active use of biological agents (e.g. TNF inhibitors, interleukin inhibitors) or  other immunosuppressive drugs.  - Patients with hemoglobinopathy.  - Patients with diabetes mellitus.  - Patients with serious obesity.  - Patients with a history of transplantation.  - Patients with immunodeficiencies.  - Patients with quadriplegia – neurological diseases with pulmonary problems.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221165302/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/12022021_Statement%20by%20the%20Minister%20of%20Health.pdf

A, C  In connection with the launching of the vaccination campaign, the Ministry of Health received permission from the government to issue two extraordinary measures relating to vaccination against COVID-19, coming into effect 14 January. The first allows vaccination against COVID-19 to be carried out on all clients of domestic health insurance companies who express an interest, in line with the vaccination strategy. On the 14th of October, 2020, there was a statement by MSP stating that it has already started actions to prepare the country for the application of the vaccine against COVID-19, of which the Government has committed a sufficient amount as soon as it is available .    The Vice Minister of Collective Health, Dr. Ivelisse Acosta explained that an international consultancy has been hired to design the logistics for the application of the vaccine and determine the equipment and training needs of the health service personnel who will work in this program.    He said that these tasks began last Friday and that first of all all people who work in the health service, the elderly and people with comorbidity (diabetes, high blood pressure and others) will be vaccinated. According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order:  - Residents in nursing homes, etc. & People aged = 65 years who receive both personal care and practical assistance.  - Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.  - Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.  - Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130122057/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Vaccinationskalender-A4-webtilgaengelig.ashx?la=da&hash=5234BB82243B24FD492FDDAC1388CA9A22BC83D6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123050/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination-against-COVID-19/Target-groups  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123058/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Specificeret-vaccinationskalender.ashx?la=da&hash=C2818CB774B7C56FCC64981CD7D6B3752EA026AF      The first approved vaccine against COVID-19 is called Comirnaty® and was developed by the German company BioNTech in collaboration with the American company Pfizer. The deliveries of Comirnaty® that we receive to Denmark are produced in factories in Germany and Belgium.   The second vaccine, which is approved for use in the EU and thus Denmark, has been developed by the American company Moderna. COVID-19 vaccine Moderna® is developed on the same technology as Comirnaty®, and is produced in factories in Switzerland and Spain. H7: THE GOVERNMENT of Prime Minister Sanna Marin (SDP) on Wednesday came to an agreement on its strategy for deploying vaccines against the new coronavirus.  “To protect the entire population, the vaccine will be offered [for free] to everyone who wants it and who doesn’t have health-related contraindications to being vaccinated,” Minister of Family Affairs and Social Services Krista Kiuru (SDP) was quoted as saying late yesterday evening by YLE.  The government presently expects to be able to commence the vaccinations of social and health care professionals who treat coronavirus patients or work in nursing homes in January, provided that at least one of the vaccines is granted market authorisation by the European Commission in December. The vaccinations of social and health care professionals could be wrapped up by February or March.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201208050644/https://www.helsinkitimes.fi/finland/finland-news/domestic/18381-finland-to-offer-covid-19-vaccine-to-everyone-starting-with-health-care-staff.html

According to the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health: "No vaccine candidate has yet been granted a marketing authorisation. Finland’s priority is to immunise the whole population once a safe and effective vaccine is approved for use in the EU."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221191413/https://stm.fi/en/coronavirus-vaccines

A:    Finland's vaccination campaign started on 27 December, with front-line ICU healthcare workers in Helsinki being the first recipients of the vaccine.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104183537/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/1271139/healthcare-and-social-welfare-workers-first-in-line-to-get-authorised-covid-19-vaccines-on-voluntary-basis

Most of these vaccinations will be carried out in January–February 2021.   The vaccine will then be offered to elderly persons and to those with diseases that predispose them to severe coronavirus disease. After that, the vaccine will be offered to the rest of the population. It is still unclear when the vaccine can be offered to everyone willing to be vaccinated because the schedule mainly depends on the marketing authorisations and the availability of the vaccines.

A, C:    The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

A, C:    Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn

A,C:     As of February 5th, over 2 million vaccinations have given in France https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    PfizerBiontech and Moderna are being administered, with the AztraZeneca vaccine available as of February 6th. Following approval by EMA on January 29th 2020, the Haute autorité de santé (HAS) approved the AstraZeneca vaccine for use with two groups: "people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, whatever their age; and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with co-morbidities" per https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    France24 reported that first doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine were administered to health workers on Feb 6 2021 at "The Hospices Civils de Lyon, which received 7,700 doses on Friday evening [...] began to vaccinate their nursing staff and liberal doctors on Saturday afternoon at the Édouard-Herriot hospital, according to their press service." https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213549/https://www.france24.com/fr/france/20210206-covid-19-premi%C3%A8res-injections-du-vaccin-d-astrazeneca-en-france    This addition will expand availability to Group B (clinically vulnerable groups), adding this cohort to existing Key Worker and Elderly groups that are eligible for vaccination. Although the first doses of the AstraZeneva vaccine were delivered to France on February 6th, injection of people will begin "As soon as the quantities delivered allow it, it can be administered by town doctors, then, subsequently, in local pharmacies, for people meeting the criteria required by the HAS (people aged 50 to 64, starting with those with comorbidities). The exact date of initiation of vaccination for these people will be communicated very soon, depending on the doses available." so coding remains as 2G, but should move to 3G in the near future.

As part of the imminent start of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19, the Minister of Health, Dr. Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong visited, this Tuesday March 16, 2021, the vaccination centers of the University Hospital Centers of Libreville, d 'Owendo and the Jeanne Ebori Foundation in the presence of the President of the Scientific Committee of the Copil coronavirus, Pr. Marielle Bouyou Akotet.    It was for the member of the government to inquire about the level of preparation of these structures as a prelude  to the said vaccination campaign and the patient circuit.    In terms of organization, the Owendo University Hospital has set up a spacious room including two vaccination posts, three observation chairs and a cold room.    At the University Hospital of Libreville, there are five vaccination posts spread over two pavilions, a main one with two vaccination rooms, two observation rooms, a waiting room, a cold room and a data entry office and a second pavilion, in development course, which will consist of three vaccination rooms, a waiting room, an observation room and an entry room.    Finally, at the Jeanne Ebori foundation mother-child hospital, a large room with five vaccination and observation posts has been set up and is ready to welcome patients.    At the end of this visit, the Minister of Health expressed his satisfaction with the arrangements made by the three CHUs for the smooth running of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19.    It should be noted that the teams in charge of this vaccination will each be made up of anesthetists, senior anesthesia-resuscitation technicians (TSAR), psychologists, nurses, Red Cross volunteers and vaccination agents. previously trained.  Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322071135/https://infocovid.ga/visite-des-centres-de-vaccination-dans/

On 21 January, the national action plan for vaccination was approved. The plan seeks to make sure that 60% of the population are vaccinated by the end of 2021. According to the plan, the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated first.    Only those vaccines that enjoy authorization from the World Health Organization will be imported into the country, stated Georgian Prime Minister Giorgi Gakharia.    "As you know, at the previous Cabinet meeting, the Health Ministry was instructed to finalize the national action plan for vaccination, to make sure that it is approved by today's Cabinet meeting. The relevant working group was created on December 15 to bring together all stakeholders, including experts, international partners, field specialists, epidemiologists, doctors, the Public Defender, and others," Giorgi Gakharia said.    "Alongside its key goal, equally important is the plan's technical aspect, including timeframe and target groups to vaccinated in stages according to this timeframe. Allow me to emphasize that the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated at the initial stage, meaning medical personnel, long-term care facility residents, our senior citizens aged 75 and over, and then all our citizens aged between 65 and 75," Giorgi Gakharia stated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130050759/https://stopcov.ge/en/News/Article/Prime_Minister%E2%80%99s_Statements_at_Cabinet_Meeting

On February 24, Ghana received 600,000 vaccine doses through COVAX and they are scheduled to roll out to the public on March 2.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

A, B, C: AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine  Ghana was one of the first countries to receive vaccines through COVAX. 600,000 doses were received on February 24 and they started to administer them to the public on March 2. The Health service has published vaccination site information in different districts around the country. A main goal of the COVAX initiative is to provide doses for at least 20% of countries' populations. Ghana aims to vaccinate 20 million Ghanians by the end of 2021. Due to the criteria above, I have coded Ghana as a 2. There is no evidence of cost for recipients; the vaccine was funded by the COVAX initiative.   "So, from Tuesday, 2nd March, to Monday, 15th March 2021, the Ghana Health Service will begin deployment of the six hundred thousand (600,000) AstraZeneca vaccines, with persons in Groups 1 and 2 being the target of this first vaccination campaign. It will be conducted in forty-three (43) districts, which are the epi-centres of the pandemic in the country. They are twenty-five (25) in Greater Accra, sixteen (16) in Ashanti, and two (2) in the Central Region."   "Group 1 is categorised as “persons most at risk and frontline State officials”. It includes healthcare workers, frontline security personnel, persons with underlying medical conditions, persons sixty (60) years and above, and frontline members of the Executive, Legislature and Judiciary.  Group 2 is made up of other essential service providers and the rest of the security agencies."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307021132/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/downloads/vaccine_administration.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307020522/https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2021/03/04/971798030/ghana-greets-historic-vaccine-delivery-with-a-dose-of-skepticism

Guinea began vaccinations against COVID-19 with a Russian produced vaccine on an experimental basis. Although Dr Sakoba Keita, the Director-General of the National Health Security Agency, outlined the initiative, by saying "We have ordered 2 million doses (from Russia) to be able to vaccinate vulnerable people," government ministers were among the first to receive the vaccines during the pilot phase of the rollout in late December. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210103193105/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/31/guinea-begins-administering-russia-s-sputnik-v-covid-19-vaccine/

According to Washington Post, December 31st, 2020. Guinea began vaccinating against COVID-19 with the Russian Sputnik V vaccine on an experimental basis, starting with government officials, authorities said Thursday.    Guinea has ordered only 55 doses of the Russian vaccine, said Dr. Sakoba Keita, the director-general of the National Health Security Agency.    “We requested a small quantity of the vaccine, 55 doses precisely. This is the beginning of an order,” Keita said. “Yesterday we vaccinated in this pilot phase 25 senior officials of the state. There are 30 doses left and we will continue with the vaccination.”    However, he said on state TV Wednesday that they also sent a letter to Russia requesting 2 million doses of Sputnik V to help the country’s vulnerable. Guinea has a population of 13 million.    Guinea is one of the first African nations to vaccinate its officials.  The Minister of Defense, Mohamed Diane was the first to receive the vaccine. He was shown getting the inoculation on national TV followed by other Cabinet ministers receiving the shots on Wednesday.    Gen. Bourema Condé, Minister of Territorial Administration and Decentralization, spoke after receiving the Russian vaccine.    “This new vaccine is a strong signal. This signal shows the strong will of the president. Today is a sampling, and this sampling will be duplicated,” he said. “The president wants all Guineans to be in good health in relation to this pandemic.”    Amadou Damaro Camara, the president of the country’s legislative body, the National Assembly, was also vaccinated.    “We are the guinea pigs,” he said of receiving the first doses of the vaccine.    “It is the government’s permanent concern to want to fight against this disease and we are very happy about it,” he said. “We hope that this vaccination will be extended to the rest of the people and that it will be the beginning of the eradication of this disease.”  Tibou Camara, Guinea’s industry minister, also spoke on the television broadcast after being vaccinated.    “The Guinean population should be congratulated and rejoice at a time when the vaccine is coveted and not very accessible to many countries, and that our country is a beneficiary,” he said.    Russia has businesses in the West African nation and Guinea is known for its bauxite mining.    Russian President Vladimir Putin was among the first world leaders to congratulate Guinea’s President Alpha Conde after he won a controversial third term in office after a violently contested election in October.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111080426/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/guinea-uses-russian-covid-19-vaccine-on-some-officials/2020/12/31/bcf30562-4b5f-11eb-97b6-4eb9f72ff46b_story.html
Vaccine still at pilot phase.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118235356/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/31/guinea-begins-administering-russia-s-sputnik-v-covid-19-vaccine/

Guinea is the only country, among the 29 world's poorest, to have a vaccination plan. However, only 55 people have been vaccinated in a pilot phase (with Sputnik V). There is no information about the number of doses that will be available and starting from when.

Around 55 people - mainly government officials - were vaccinated during the pilot phase, but no comprehensive vaccination policy is evident beyond this. The country got free vaccines.   Guinea on Wednesday received a donation of 200,000 Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses from China as it seeks help from multiple sources to halt the spread of the coronavirus, foreign affairs minister Ibrahima Khalil Kaba told Reuters.    The West African nation of around 12 million is awaiting its first shipment of 864,000 doses from the global vaccine-sharing scheme COVAX, which started deliveries to developing countries last week.  Guinean authorities are also in talks to obtain 400,000 doses of Russia’s Sputnik V COVID-19, a health ministry official said last month.    Sixty doses of the Russian vaccine were previously provided on an experimental basis, with President Alpha Conde and some ministers among those inoculated. Note: Gambia is preparing to receive vaccines from COVAX (most likely Oxford/AZ) and is finalising preparations for the vaccine rollout. The priority is to give the first injections to frontline health workers and other vulnerable groups such as the elderly and those with underlying medical conditions. See http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2021-03/02/content_77261256.htm [web archive unavailable]

The government of The Gambia has approved Astrazeneca as COVID-19 vaccine for use.  On 3rd March Gambia has received its first shipment of 36,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines through the COVAX Facility, less than a week after the Ministry of Health submitted the required documentation for the delivery of the vaccines to the country. The AstraZeneca vaccines were shipped by UNICEF on behalf of COVAX, from the Serum Institute of India (SII), and arrived at the Banjul International Airport late Tuesday night.  More shipments of COVID-19 vaccines and syringes are expected in the coming weeks.   The country plans to vaccinate frontline health workers, people who are 65 and above and those with co-morbidities in the first round of the campaign, Bittaye said. The start date of the vaccination drive hasn’t yet been confirmed, he said.    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/wca/press-releases/first-tranche-covid-19-vaccines-arrives-gambia-covax-initiative  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-03/gambia-set-to-start-vaccinations-after-covax-senegal-donations

Vaccines are not yet being administered, but there is a government-funded policy in place:    Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis met with advisors and government ministers virtually on Saturday 5 December 20202 in order to discuss the country’s Covid-19 vaccination plan.    Reportedly, vaccinations will begin in January, with healthcare workers having priority. Greeks will be able to make appointments to receive the free shot at one of the country’s 1,018 vaccination centers that are currently being created in order to best distribute the vaccine to as many people as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209210724/https://greece.greekreporter.com/2020/12/05/greece-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-in-january-1383-new-cases-saturday/

The Greek Ministry of Health has developed a priority system for COVID-19 vaccination and system for appointments, available on the Greek government webpage at https://emvolio.gov.gr/. The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 75 and above, individuals age 60-65, and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization.  The vaccination phase for individuals age 70-74 opened as of March 26, 2021. So, priority groups currently are the elderly and those with co-morbidities. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330075700/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy:  The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 60 and above and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization. Notably, 70 and above were previously considered one group at initial rollout, 60 and above were incorporated as a priority group as of April 2nd, however, these were not classified as a third group because they all fall into the general "elderly" category.   Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224182107/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403121028/https://www.ekathimerini.com/news/1158463/greece-s-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-expands-to-65-69-age-group/

Vaccinations (Pfizer/BioNTech) have been carried out in the main cities of entry, namely Nuuk, Ilulissat, Aasiaat, Sisimiut and Qaqortoq. The target groups have been everyone aged 65 and over, health and care workers, as well as people who are medically assessed to be at particular risk of serious illness. A successful co-operation project with the Arctic Command has also been carried out, where vaccinations have been carried out in Qeqertarsuatsiaat and Paamiut.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329104455/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2021/03/2603_Vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329105554/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/greenland/

Greenland has a vaccination strategy where the delivery of vaccines is directly affected by the vaccine supply provided to Denmark. The vaccine type is issued by Pfizer/BioNtech. The population groups that will be vaccinated first include the elderly, physically vulnerable, chronically ill and relevant health care personnel. The number of vaccines shipped to Greenland is scarce, and therefore the vaccinations will be periodically rolled out according to target group prioritisations and residency location. The locals will be contacted directly when their group is next in line for the vaccine:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401155951/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

Updated on December 3rd, the government, a member of the COVAX facility, has prepaid about one seventh of the total cost for 6.7 million doses of vaccines and, since a double dose is required, it will vaccinate 3.4 million people, about one fifth of the population. In mid-November, the Ministry of Health created the National Coordination Committee for Vaccination against COVID-19 with the purpose to coordinate the National Strategic Plan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205091344/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In addition, the authorities engaged in bilateral negotiations with two laboratories seeking to cover their entire adult population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221081002/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

A    The GTM government, a member of the COVAX facility, has prepaid about one seventh of the total cost purchase for 6.74 million doses of vaccines and since a double dose is required, it will vaccinate 3.37 million people, about one fifth of the population. Covax has recently closed negotiations with AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson and Sanofi. In addition, the government has been engaged in bilateral negotiations with two pharmaceuticals, AstraSeneca and Moderna, seeking to cover its entire adult population.. The vaccine will be applied first to doctors, nurses, firefighters, police and soldiers. Pregnant women and children under the age of 18 will not be able to receive the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111150322/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Department of Public Health and Social Services (DPHSS) placed its first order of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines on December 4 for 3,900 doses. It has been given authorization to place its next order in the next 24 to 48 hours for a minimum of  3,900 doses. This number is subject to change.   Additionally, DPHSS has placed its first order of Moderna vaccines, or vaccine B, on Saturday, December 12, for a total of 3,800 doses. The Moderna vaccine must still undergo the same review and approval process as the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine before distribution begins to states and territories.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201215020809/https://guamrecovery.com/jic-release-no-492-dphss-anticipates-arrival-of-first-vaccine-order-by-end-of-week-dphss-issues-guidance-memo-no-2020-45/

These clinics will administer first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and second doses of both the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.   PHASE 1a/1b/1c – CATEGORY: Healthcare workers; local and federal law enforcement personnel; School-based employees and Childcare Center employees; adults 40 years and older; Mayors’ Council of Guam (limited to mayors, vice mayors, and mayoral staff); funeral homes, mortuary, and cemetery staff; service providers contracted with the DPHSS Division of Senior Citizens providing direct patient or client care such as transportation for medical appointments, homebound meals, in-home services, caregiver services, case management, shelter care, adult daycare, and other direct services; and others who are due for dose two of the vaccine. On December 11, Hong Kong Leader announced the government had signed advanced purchase agreements to procure 7.5 million vaccines, the first batch of which could arrive as early as January. The government’s plan was to stock up enough doses for two full inoculations for each of the city’s 7.5 million residents. The authorities will manage the purchase, administration and prioritization of the jabs.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201212095025/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3113667/covid-19-vaccines-hong-kong-how-safe-are-they-and

The Government published the Use of Vaccines Regulation on December 23, which provides the legal framework for emergency use of COVID-19 vaccines.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201228084947/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202012/24/P2020122300963.htm?fontSize=1

'Hong Kong can start vaccinations for Covid-19 in early March if everything goes as planned, the city’s Civil Service Secretary Patrick Nip said.  The first batch of vaccines from the German firm BioNTech SE should arrive at the end of this month, Nip said, according to a transcript of his comments to reporters provided by the government. Vaccines will be administered via an advance booking process, he said.  The government will offer the shots at community vaccination centers in 18 districts of Hong Kong, said Nip, who is in charge of Covid-19 vaccinations in the city.'    https://archive.vn/zBOSl  https://archive.vn/nw5B0

Widespread vaccination by Sept. 2021    Mostafa Ghane'ei, an official with the Vice Presidency for Science and Technology, said that the domestically produced COVID-19 vaccine will probably be injected into the whole population in the [next Iranian calendar year] month of Mehr (starting September 23, 2021).    Emphasizing that no Iranian vaccine has been yet allowed to enter the human phase so far, he said that “progress is made when the Food and Drug Administration issues a vaccine clinical work permit.”    All vaccines are in the pre-clinical stage and it is hoped that at least 4 vaccines to start phase 3 of the human trial in September 2021, he highlighted.    Now that coronavirus vaccines have been developed in the world and the third phase of clinical trials has passed, the possible side effects are almost certain, and Iran will be aware of the side effects which speeds up the process, he noted, adding, “vaccines produced in Iran are the same as those produced in China, India, the United States, etc.”    Iraj Harirchi, the deputy minister of health, has said that in Iran, 12 groups are making efforts to develop coronavirus vaccine, three of which have passed the animal testing.    Last week, Namaki expressed hope that the country will introduce the home-grown COVID-19 vaccine by the end of the current Iranian calendar year (March 19, 2021).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201215165940/https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/454829/High-hopes-for-COVID-19-vaccine-in-Iran

Mass vaccination against COVID-19   started in Iran on February 9, with the priority given to medical staff, the elderly, and people with underlying diseases, President Hassan Rouhani announced.  Iran imported the Sputnik V vaccine from Russia.   Importing vaccine from COVAX, a global initiative to ensure rapid and equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, is also on the agenda. And already the first shipment of the COVAX vaccine was delivered.  Iranian scientists have been working on developing domestic vaccines against the coronavirus, two of which are in the human trial phase.    Coviran Barekat, the first coronavirus vaccine made by Iranian researchers of the Headquarters for Executing the Order of the Imam, was unveiled and injected into three volunteers during a ceremony on December 29, 2020.    The second COVID-19 vaccine is a product of the Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute. Razi COV-Pars — an mRNA recombinant vaccine — is administered via injection and inhalation.    https://archive.vn/nltAB  https://archive.vn/rdoy1  https://archive.vn/GwPbY  https://archive.vn/zmFUK  https://archive.vn/LzSYI

Iraq is expected to receive its first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine by February, according to Iraq’s Health Minister on Monday.     Last month, the ministry announced it had signed a preliminary deal with the vaccine makers to import 1.5 million doses by early 2021. Health Ministry spokesperson Saif al-Badr confirmed this week with state-owned newspaper al-Sabah that Iraq’s share of the vaccine is now 8 million doses, enough to cover 20% of the country’s population. Troops, health care workers and the elderly are prioritized for vaccines, Badr had said in December.     “The distribution will be made to all governorates through hospitals to be determined through the media and according to priority,” he told al-Sabah on Monday. “The vaccine will not be compulsory at all.”        Read more: https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2021/01/iraq-baghdad-coronavirus-vaccine-covax.html#ixzz6jwM9BWXS

Health Ministry spokesman Seif al-Badr said Friday that most of the new infections were in western Baghdad, as well as the two shrine cities of Najaf and Karbala.    Among Najaf's cases is 91-year-old Grand Ayatollah Mohammad al-Fayyad, one of the top four Shiite clerics in the country led by Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani.    His office confirmed that he tested positive but said his condition was stable.    Badr also told AFP that a first batch of three million doses of vaccines was due to arrive "in the coming days".  "We have ordered three million, up to 3.5 million, vaccines from AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, as well as Pfizer," he said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222184355/https://medicalxpress.com/news/2021-02-iraq-covid-cases-lockdown.html

No vaccine yet available in Iraq  COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Iraq approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? No  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314204822/https://iq.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Iraq began coronavirus vaccinations on Tuesday, inoculating medical staff hours after a military plane brought in 50,000 Sinopharm jabs donated by China. Aside from health workers, security forces and the elderly will be first to receive the free-of-charge vaccine, his ministry said on a citizens’ registration platform     https://web.archive.org/web/20210330022659/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1818796/middle-east

A national vaccination campaign has launched that "will be distributed fairly and safely, and will reach all citizens free of charge" but health workers, security forces and the elderly will be first to receive the free-of-charge vaccine, his ministry said on a citizens’ registration platform.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330022659/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1818796/middle-east  https://web.archive.org/web/20210309193427/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/iraq-starts-coronavirus-vaccination-campaign/2162374

Particular importance will be placed on vaccinating persons who are in the frontline in the battle against the pandemic. This applies to healthcare workers and others working in emergency departments and intensive care units in hospitals, on COVID-19 wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19, healthcare workers who perform screening tests in cases of suspected COVID-19 and the staff of nursing and retirement homes. The vaccination of persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals will also have high priority.    There are ten priority groups. The groups with the greatest priority consist of a relatively few number of people; the first five groups are estimated to number around 20,000 persons.    Group 6: Persons aged 60 and older    Group 7: Persons with underlying long-term illnesses    Group 8: Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers    Group 9: Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation    And finally, Group 10: All others who request vaccination, as determined by the Chief Epidemiologist.    The regulation makes no provision for the COVID-19 vaccination of children born 2006 or later unless such children have an underlying long-term illness and are members of a special risk group.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

A, C:    Iceland received the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine on December 28 and vaccination began on December 29. At the moment, Iceland is expecting to receive vaccine for at least 30,000 people before the end of March.  COVID-19 vaccination is optional and free of charge in Iceland. Vaccines are being administered according to priority groups defined by health authorities, though the Chief Epidemiologist may grant exceptions to that order. The first to be vaccinated were frontline healthcare workers and nursing home residents. According to the current vaccination schedule, the next priority groups are people over the age of 70, paramedics who transport COVID-19 patients, and some additional healthcare workers        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106190138/https://www.icelandreview.com/ask-ir/whats-the-status-of-covid-19-vaccination-in-iceland/      http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine
A, C  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210117080054/https://www.covid.is/covid-19-vaccine
A, C:

A, C:    There are ten priority groups:   "Group 1  Healthcare professionals and other staff working in emergency wards and intensive care units of Landspítali University Hospital and the intensive care unit in the hospital in Akureyri.  Group 2  Healthcare workers working in COVID-19 out-patient wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19.  Group 3  Persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals.  Group 4  Ambulance staff, paramedics, the employees of the Icelandic Coast Guard, fire brigade employees, prison guards, call-out police officers.  Group 5  Healthcare professionals involved in the primary care of patients and who must necessarily be vaccinated.  Group 6  Persons aged 60 and older.  Groups 7  Persons with underlying long-term illnesses who are at particular risk.  Groups 8  Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers.  Groups 9  Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation.  Groups 10  All others who request vaccination."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210203164947/https://www.covid.is/covid-19-vaccine     As of 02 Feb 2021, the government is vaccinating up to group 6:   "Vaccinations are taking place between between 9:00 and 15:00 at Suðurlandsbraut 34 today. These will be for people in priority group six; a group of 2,600 people, 70% of which have already started vaccinating in nursing homes."   Both Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are being administered.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210202140059/https://grapevine.is/news/2021/02/02/more-covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-iceland/    The next group, Group 7, will include B, our "clinically vulnerable groups".
