HMOs are offering the vaccine to all members over 16. The army is vaccinating forces. The percentage of the population vaccinated is now over 47% indicating both availability and delivery. Vaccination is voluntary.    "The majority of the Israeli population will be vaccinated. In the first stage, certain groups, such as children (under 16 years of age) and recovered patients, will not be vaccinated due to a lack of information about vaccination among these populations."    Percentage of vaccinated in the total population: 21/2  	• 47.06% first dose vaccinated  	• 32.29% second dose vaccinated    Who will get the vaccine first?  	• The vaccine is given to individuals who are 16 years of age or older.  	• Pregnant women or women who plan to be pregnant can get the vaccine.   	• People with an acute illness, especially if their body temperature is 38 degrees Celsius or higher, should recover before getting the vaccine.    Who will not get the vaccine at this stage?  	• People who are younger than 16 years of age.  	• People with a history of severe allergic reactions. They are required to tell staff before they are vaccinated and ask if they can have the vaccine.  	• Certified recovered COVID-19 patients.    Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210224150712if_/https://datadashboard.health.gov.il/COVID-19/general    https://web.archive.org/web/20210223153943/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/covid19-vaccine/en-covid19-vaccination-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226115508/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/covid19-vaccine/en-covid19-vaccine-faqs/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226113624/https://www.timesofisrael.com/poll-some-25-of-israelis-who-havent-vaccinated-have-no-intention-of-doing-so/

Jordan on Wednesday began its vaccination campaign against the coronavirus pandemic, with healthcare workers and the elderly prioritized for the first shots.    Dr. Daoud Hanania, the country’s former director of medical services, became the first person to receive the injection in an event aired by state TV.    Health Minister Nazir Obeidat earlier said that the vaccination program will prioritize the most vulnerable groups including the elderly, those who suffer from chronic diseases, and medical personnel.    According to the Health Ministry, 29 centers across the kingdom will receive the vaccines.    The jabs arrived in Jordan on Saturday and Monday, starting with 3,800 tons of the Chinese Sinopharm virus vaccine and the Pfizer-BioNTech respectively, according to official media sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118223154/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/jordan-begins-covid-19-vaccine-rollout/2108497

The country continues to roll out covid-19 vaccine and more information is released to the media outlet as we move forward in time. Kazakhstan citizens receive free vaccination and vaccination is voluntary in the country. The vaccine currently used in Kazakhstan is the Sputnik V vaccine, which is contraindicated for children under 18. The following groups of key workers will be vaccinated at the first stage: healthcare workers of, infectious diseases hospitals, ambulance, intensive care units, emergency hospitals, hospital admissions and sanitary and epidemiological service.     https://archive.is/h64OJ

Sputnik V consists of 2 stages. Currently, about 28,388 people received the vaccine stage 1, and about 14933 people received the vaccine stage 2. Now, only key workers are receiving vaccines. It is planned to vaccinate vulnerable people from April 1.  Link: https://archive.vn/VpOYW

As of March 31, more than 173 thousand people in Kazakhstan received at least one dose of the Russian Sputnik V vaccine. First of all, doctors, key workers - police officers, teachers, who are in contact with a large number of people, have been vaccinated. From April, the government is planning to start vaccinating elderly people.     Kazakhstan launched local production of the Russia-developed vaccine (Sputnik V) in December 2020 and started voluntary vaccination of the local population on February 1. The authorities plan to vaccinate six million people (about one third of the population) free of charge by end-2021. The first stage vaccination is expected to cover groups with high risk exposure, including doctors, teachers, and law enforcement workers. In addition, a locally developed vaccine (QazCovid-in) and the vaccine developed by Pfizer/BioNTech are expected to be available later in the year. Mass vaccination is expected to start after priority groups complete vaccination, likely in May. The authorities are also conducting an awareness campaign about vaccination, including recent statements by the President to counter misinformation about the vaccines.  Links: https://archive.vn/W1l7I https://archive.vn/Eau3N https://archive.vn/IG3zg

On December 8th, the Korean government secures up to 44 million vaccines for COVID-19. The government announced that it will pre-purchase overseas vaccines for up to 44 million people through COVAX Facility (for about 10 million people) and global vaccine companies (for about 34 million people). The pre-purchased vaccine is expected to be introduced in stages from the first quarter of 2021 (February and March); however, the later distribution may vary depending on ongoing clinical trial results and close monitoring. The Kuwaiti Ministry of Health webpage (https://www.moh.gov.kw) allows residents of Kuwait, including U.S. citizen residents, to pre-register for the COVID-19 vaccine by clicking on “COVID-19 Vaccination Pre-Registration.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301195154/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The disparity in Kuwait’s campaign has triggered an online debate between those nationals defending the policy and outraged expatriates and Kuwaitis who feel the pro-citizen push is flavored by racism.    There were signs of a shift on Wednesday, with expat residents of Kuwait saying that more elderly foreigners were seen at inoculation centers.  An initially slow vaccination program gained momentum with the opening of more inoculation centers and the arrival of doses made by Oxford University/AstraZeneca. Kuwait says it’s prioritizing all frontline workers and those in high-risk groups.  https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=e6ddafd0-7acb-11eb-aab9-4d3d4aa651bf&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0wMi0xOC9rdXdhaXQtcHV0cy1jaXRpemVucy1iZWZvcmUtZXhwYXRzLWFzLXZhY2NpbmUtcHVzaC1zdGlycy1hbmdlcg==    Distributed vaccine  As the fifth shipment of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in Kuwait this week, the total number of doses received reached 550,000, with 150,000 in the first shipment and 100,000 in every other shipment following, a source told Al Jarida.    The Pfizer vaccine is being prioritized for those above the age of 65 and between the ages of 16-17, as only those above the age of 18 can receive the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine. https://web.archive.org/web/20210301202818/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/kuwait/covid-19-no-deaths-from-taking-vaccine-says-kuwait-ministry-of-health-1.77489540    Ministry of Health yesterday started providing COVID-19 vaccination for residents at the Kuwait Vaccination Center in Mishref particularly for the elderly and those suffering from chronic and immunological diseases, as these groups are most at risk of the COVID-19 infection and the occurrence of complications.

Has the government of Kuwait approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes.  The Kuwaiti Ministry of Health webpage (https://www.moh.gov.kw) allows residents of Kuwait, including U.S. citizen residents, to pre-register for the COVID-19 vaccine by clicking on “COVID-19 Vaccination Pre-Registration.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314213621/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    By mid-February 2021, around 119,000 Kuwaitis but only 18,000 migrant workers had been vaccinated, a Bloomberg report revealed. "We feel like we have the right to be vaccinated too, because we are here to serve them [the Kuwaitis]. We mostly work in the front line, in restaurants, to deliver food, drive taxis, so being vaccinated is something like protection," Krishna told me.    Kuwait’s citizen-first approach to public policy, of which the discriminatory vaccination campaign is the latest symbol, underlines a barely concealed de facto caste system that is the cornerstone of modern Gulf economies. https://web.archive.org/web/20210315194914/https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/.premium-vaccine-nationalism-in-the-gulf-kuwait-s-cruel-covid-caste-system-1.9617911

Lao PDR today received its first shipment of COVID-19 vaccine doses through the COVAX facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF and the World Health Organisation  The shipment consists of 132,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India (SII), and was shipped by air to the Wattay International Airport in Vientiane from Pune, India. This batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines is the first of the total of 480,000 doses being planned for delivery to Lao PDR via the COVAX initiative this year to cover about 20 percent of the total population.  According the country’s National Deployment and Vaccination Plan (NVDP), this initial batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines will be used by the Government of Lao PDR to first immunise priority groups in the country who are at greater risk of exposure to COVID-19 and those who are most likely to develop severe symptoms from infection.    This includes frontline healthcare workers, older adults above the age of 60 and people with underlying health conditions. Some essential workers will also be prioritised based on the nature of the job and high-risk of exposure to COVID-19 such as workers at points of entry and in quarantine centres.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210405183726/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-vaccines-shipped-by-covax-facility-arrive-in-lao-pdr/

The government has begun vaccinating the most vulnerable and at-risk groups in a step towards ending the acute phase of the Covid-19 pandemic.  The national rollout of COVAX-supported vaccines began at Mittaphab Hospital in Vientiane on Friday (April 2).  The vaccines were received on March 20 and were provided by the COVAX Facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF, and the World Health Organisation (WHO).  The shipment consisted of 132,000 doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India.  This shipment is the first of Laos’ initial allocation of 480,000 doses. COVAX aspires to provide enough vaccine to supply at least 20 percent of the population this year, according to a press release from UNICEF.   the priority groups comprise healthcare workers, adults above the age of 60, and people with underlying health conditions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412183244/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/04/05/laos-mass-rollout-of-covid-19-vaccine-gets-underway
Vaccine open for foreigner as well.    US Web Archived for Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182114/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

https://archive.vn/YVFlR    Hasan: The Vaccination Campaign is Being Implemented Systematically     A year after the pandemic, we succeeded in developing the public health sector in an unprecedented      manner, said Dr. Hamad Hassan, minister of public health in the caretaker government, said that "the vaccination campaign proved a week after its launch that it is being implemented in a good and systematic form, despite some breaches that are being dealt with quickly in some centres."  "The success rate on the national registration platform is rapidly rising and adjusted according to the need, such as rounding up the appointments of people who are immediately following their appointments to those who may miss the vaccination, which will ensure that no vaccine dose is  lost."  "The bumps we experienced in the face of the pandemic were very difficult, especially the epidemic, which resulted from the easing of the holidays and the repercussions of the port explosion," Hassan told Al-Mayadeen tv, marking the one-year anniversary of the Corona virus  outbreak. "The vaccine has provided an additional factor that works in response to the epidemic in addition to preventive behaviour," he said.  "In the coming period, there will be multiple vaccines, which will be free for the Lebanese," he said, stressing the adoption of the principles of justice and transparency.  "Lebanon will receive 250,000 Pfizer vaccines by the end of March, with shipments to continue until 2.1 million vaccines are reached," he said.  "Lebanon has started quick talks with the company to secure more of this vaccine, which has been proven effective by research," he  said.  He continued: "The Ministry of Health had booked two million and 555,000 doses with the Kovacs platform, and the receipt of 1.5 million vaccines from AstraZeneca was finally signed.  As for the Russian vaccine, contrary to what is rumored, we went to the embassy early last September with a book to get the vaccine and secure a donation and negotiations are continuing until now, and the ministry has also begun to study the Chinese vaccine file after completing the documents."  "The import of the Russian vaccine through the Ministry of Public Health ensures that sensitive shipping conditions are secured at temperatures below 18 degrees, or through a tripartite agreement that will provide community initiatives with more vaccines," he  said.  The minister of health was surprised by the "continued media confusion over the performance of the Ministry of Public Health, such as the rumor that the Pfizer vaccine will not be handed over to Lebanon for certain political reasons, or that the Ministry of Health was competent in distributing equipment and equipment to hospitals and much more misinformation."        "The ministry responds to repeated allegations of compliance with the plans and the serious performance on the ground that reflects the positives of all Lebanese, and the reality is that pfizer's vaccine has arrived on its stated dates in Lebanon, and the equipment has been distributed to all hospitals in all regions without discrimination, and international institutions are dealing with confidence and effectiveness with the ministry despite attempts by some to harm this relationship," he  said.  "One year after the pandemic, the public health sector's horizon looks different," Hassan  said. This sector has been supported in an orderly, systematic and unprecedented manner in terms of equipping government hospitals with intensive care rooms and state-of-the-art equipment and equipment. "These hospitals have won the confidence of the Lebanese in their various segments and classes."

https://archive.vn/YVFlR    Hasan: The Vaccination Campaign is Being Implemented Systematically     A year after the pandemic, we succeeded in developing the public health sector in an unprecedented      manner, said Dr. Hamad Hassan, minister of public health in the caretaker government, said that "the vaccination campaign proved a week after its launch that it is being implemented in a good and systematic form, despite some breaches that are being dealt with quickly in some centres."  "The success rate on the national registration platform is rapidly rising and adjusted according to the need, such as rounding up the appointments of people who are immediately following their appointments to those who may miss the vaccination, which will ensure that no vaccine dose is  lost."  "The bumps we experienced in the face of the pandemic were very difficult, especially the epidemic, which resulted from the easing of the holidays and the repercussions of the port explosion," Hassan told Al-Mayadeen tv, marking the one-year anniversary of the Corona virus  outbreak. "The vaccine has provided an additional factor that works in response to the epidemic in addition to preventive behaviour," he said.  "In the coming period, there will be multiple vaccines, which will be free for the Lebanese," he said, stressing the adoption of the principles of justice and transparency.  "Lebanon will receive 250,000 Pfizer vaccines by the end of March, with shipments to continue until 2.1 million vaccines are reached," he said.  "Lebanon has started quick talks with the company to secure more of this vaccine, which has been proven effective by research," he  said.  He continued: "The Ministry of Health had booked two million and 555,000 doses with the Kovacs platform, and the receipt of 1.5 million vaccines from AstraZeneca was finally signed.  As for the Russian vaccine, contrary to what is rumored, we went to the embassy early last September with a book to get the vaccine and secure a donation and negotiations are continuing until now, and the ministry has also begun to study the Chinese vaccine file after completing the documents."  "The import of the Russian vaccine through the Ministry of Public Health ensures that sensitive shipping conditions are secured at temperatures below 18 degrees, or through a tripartite agreement that will provide community initiatives with more vaccines," he  said.  The minister of health was surprised by the "continued media confusion over the performance of the Ministry of Public Health, such as the rumor that the Pfizer vaccine will not be handed over to Lebanon for certain political reasons, or that the Ministry of Health was competent in distributing equipment and equipment to hospitals and much more misinformation."        "The ministry responds to repeated allegations of compliance with the plans and the serious performance on the ground that reflects the positives of all Lebanese, and the reality is that pfizer's vaccine has arrived on its stated dates in Lebanon, and the equipment has been distributed to all hospitals in all regions without discrimination, and international institutions are dealing with confidence and effectiveness with the ministry despite attempts by some to harm this relationship," he  said.  "One year after the pandemic, the public health sector's horizon looks different," Hassan  said. This sector has been supported in an orderly, systematic and unprecedented manner in terms of equipping government hospitals with intensive care rooms and state-of-the-art equipment and equipment. "These hospitals have won the confidence of the Lebanese in their various segments and classes."

TRIPOLI, April 17 (Xinhua) -- The Director of the National Center for Disease Control of Libya, Dadr Addin Annajar, on Saturday announced the start of the vaccination against COVID-19 in the capital Tripoli. Annajar revealed that Libya so far has received vaccines from China, Russia and other nations and will distribute them to different parts of the country via 450 vaccination centers. He also explained that vaccination priority will be for medical staff treating COVID-19 patients inside isolation units, followed by the elderly, those with chronic diseases, and then the health workers who do not deal with the infectious virus. Within a few weeks, a large number of people are expected to be vaccinated, Annajar added, confirming that around 500,000 people have already registered online to get the jabs.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419130621/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2021-04/18/c_139887759.htm    Since, shots have not been administered yet, recording it as 0.

On November 30th, Luxembourg issued regulations for the distribution of the covid 19 vaccines. The first groups that will benefit from this vaccine are the elderly, identified as people that are 65 years or more, and the healthcare workers.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201213172111/https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Overview-of-EU_EEA-UK-vaccination-deployment-plans.pdf

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

A,B  Phase 1 - Health professionals and staff working in hospitals and residential facilities for the elderly are among those most exposed to COVID-19, and therefore deserve special consideration and close protection. Similarly, people living in residential facilities for the elderly will be vaccinated on a priority basis.     Pfizer    Link - https://web.archive.org/web/20210110031217/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

Policy: In an initial phase, the vaccine is not available in sufficient doses for everyone to be vaccinated at the same time. It is therefore necessary and legitimate to prioritise according to the objectives of the immunisation strategy, i.e.    protect the most vulnerable people (based on their age or health status) from the risk of complications from the disease and from the risk of death, and  protect the capacity of our health care system. A:    The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

First stage of vaccination in Macao began on 9 Feb is available to three prioritized groups, including frontline government workers and those who inevitably have to travel to high-risk areas.    More detail:  'Macau began rollout of Sinopharm vaccines on 9 Feburary.  The first batch of 100,000 mainland-made two-dose Sinopharm vaccines - chosen for the first phase of Macau's program that arrived on Saturday [i.e. 6 Feb] - can cover 50,000 people.  Vaccinations started for high-risk groups yesterday, including health-care workers and disciplinary officers.  "There will also be another brand of vaccines arriving in Macau at the end of this month citizens can choose the brand they want later."  Macau rolled out vaccinations from 9am yesterday [i.e. 9 Feb], with medical workers, police, firemen and customs officers among those receiving the shot.  Vaccinations are available to three prioritized groups, including frontline government workers and those who inevitably have to travel to high-risk areas.  The next stage of vaccination, to start on February 22, will be open to other Macau residents.  The jab will be free for all residents, non-local employees with work permits, students and prisoners. It will cost 250 patacas (HK$242) for non-residents.  People working in high-risk sectors, such as frozen and fresh food handlers, care home staff, transport workers, teachers, croupiers and government security officers, are also covered.'  https://archive.vn/q4RAP    The government encourages the residents to take the vaccine when available.  https://archive.vn/pJtvM

Macau's second stage of vaccine roll-out started on 22 Feb 2021: all Macau residents are eligible to get a jab. The government calls all eligible people to book a slot.    https://archive.vn/2ZPEF  https://archive.vn/W2AER
As of 9 p.m. 25 February, 27,403 Macau residents have made appointments for vaccination, of which 10,691 have completed the vaccination with no adverse reaction appeared.    https://archive.vn/Ge7qa

By 4pm 5 April, 56,530 vaccines have been rolled out in Macau; 218 person showed reactions due to inoculations after the jab, one severe, no death.    https://archive.vn/L8Cwm

From 10am on 9th April, vaccination plan in Macao was extended to all students in Macau and non-Macau residents who are legally staying in the city; the latter group will be charged 250 Macau Pataca (c. 31.2 USD) per jab. People of these two groups can schedule their vaccination for as early as 10th April if they choose the Sinopharm vaccine and as early as 12th April if they opt for the BioNTech mRNA vaccine.    https://archive.vn/diGMy

One more hospital will start to provide Chinese vaccines with a capacity of 180 vaccinations per day from 20 April 2021. This will increase the daily capacity from the current c.5000 to c.5200. Morocco has announced a nationwide Covid-19 vaccination campaign. The campaign aims at covering 80 percent of Moroccan population over 18 years old (about 25 million people). The vaccination is expected to take place over a 3-month period, but it is not yet clear when it would start. Morocco has pre-ordered about 30 million Covid-19 vaccine doses for the vaccination campaign, and is developing partnerships to manufacture Covid-19 vaccines in Moroccan laboratories.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M

Morocco's government seeks to vaccinate 80% of its adults, or 25 million people, as soon as the vaccines are approved by domestic regulators. Priority will go to medical staff and other front-line workers, as well as the elderly. Morocco has one of the most advanced vaccination plans in the region. The country has also reported the second-highest number of virus infections and deaths in Africa, after South Africa.    The Moroccan health minister said the government’s target is vaccinating 25 million of the country’s 36 million people, all free of charge, according to orders from King Mohammed VI.  Jabs in the arms have not yet started.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162307/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/morocco-kick-mass-vaccination-plan-chinese-drug    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162312/https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/morocco-acquires-65-million-covid-19-vaccine-doses-from-china-uk

Morocco’s health ministry on Wednesday approved the COVID-19 vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and Oxford University for emergency use, Health Minister Khalid Ait Taleb said.    Morocco had announced it plans to launch a free vaccination campaign targeting 25 million people, or 80% of its population.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210117123703/https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-morocco/morocco-approves-astrazeneca-oxford-covid-19-vaccine-minister-idUSKBN29C0QA

The move came a day after the North African country received a second batch of 4 million doses of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine.    According to the Health Ministry's latest data, Morocco has vaccinated over 800,000 people since the start of its vaccination campaign.  All members of the public will be vaccinated as soon as possible, the ministry said in the statement. No change in policy.    Morocco started a nationwide Covid-19 vaccination campaign on January 28, 2021. The campaign aims at covering 80 percent of Moroccan population over 18 years old (about 25 million people). The campaign is relying on Morocco's network of primary health care institutions and mobile clinics. Priority is given to citizens in the frontline such as health workers, authority agents, security forces, teachers, elders and people with underlying health conditions. As of end-March 25, over 4.3 million persons received a first dose of vaccine and about 3.5 million are fully immunized.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419160858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    Morocco has signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire the vaccine. "Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

A:    The Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine arrived in Malta on 26th December 2020, with vaccinations of healthcare workers and frontliners starting on 27th December. People over the age of 85 will start receiving their inoculation letters from 7 January. They will be given the date and time for their first and second shots. Hence for now, only one group has vaccine access.    Source: /web/20201228065246/https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2020-12-26/local-news/First-batch-of-Covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-Malta-6736229721

A, C:    After starting vaccinating Healthcare workers, on 1st January 2021, Malta started vaccinating also people in old people's homes.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210101183322/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/woman-94-becomes-first-elderly-person-to-be-vaccinated-against-covid.842265
A,C  Pfizer, Moderna
Pfizer, Moderna

From Wednesday 27th January 2020, Malta started vaccinating Clinically vulnerable groups, together with Key workers and elderly groups. Vaccines being used are Pfizer and Moderna jabs.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201071312/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/cancer-patients-to-start-receiving-covid-19-vaccine-from-wednesday.847161

As from 10th April 2021, The Maltese government announced that the vaccine programme is now extended. Apart from the three groups of people who are already being administered the vaccine (Key workers, clinically vulnerable groups, elderly groups), the vaccine is now broadly available to anyone who wishes to be vaccinated. For now this is limited to those aged over 50. This will be then extended to younger individuals.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411070025/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/chris-fearne-covid-19-vaccines-vaccination-strategy-malta-health.863757

A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups  Myanmar has received its free first batch of Covishield, AstraZeneca’s vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India. More than 110000 Healthcare workers and volunteers will be vaccinated as part of the initial phase.   This will be followed by the government official and the elderly over the age of 65.   About 20 percent of the 54.4 million population in Myanmar will be given vaccines under the global Covax affordable medicines program and the Global Alliance for Vaccine and Immunisation.The first batch of COVID-19 vaccine under the World Health Organization’s Covax program will arrive in late February, according to the health ministry.    **Despite the military coup, Myanmar’s Ministry of Health and Sports says it is continuing with its COVID-19 vaccination program.  The ministry’s permanent secretary, Dr. Thet Khaing Win, has been named minister after the National League for Democracy’s (NLD) appointee, Dr. Myint Htwe, resigned after Monday’s coup.**  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203126/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/myanmar-health-ministry-continue-vaccinations-despite-coup.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203526/https://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-politics-india-idUSKBN2A41VE

'Mongolia will launch a nationwide COVID-19 vaccination campaign on Tuesday [23 Feb 2021], with frontline workers in health and security sectors receiving the first jabs, said Deputy Prime Minister Sainbuyan Amarsaikhan.  Amarsaikhan, also head of State Emergency Commission, made the announcement early Monday while attending the handover ceremony of 150,000 doses of the Covishield, a vaccine co-developed by the University of Oxford and pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca and produced by the Serum Institute of India.  Meanwhile, 300,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine produced by Chinese pharma company Sinovac are set to arrive on Monday night, said Health Minister Sereejav Enkhbold.  Enkhbold said that Mongolia is expected to acquire four types of COVID-19 vaccines.'    https://archive.vn/8WI6C

A. The frontline health care workers at high risk.  Mongolia launched COVID-19 Vaccination Programme on 23 FEB, 'beginning with the frontline health care workers at high risk. Government of Mongolia has received an initial 150000 doses of AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, produced by the Serum Institute of India, that has received Emergency Use Listing by the World Health Organization (WHO) and approval by Mongolia’s national regulatory authority. Following the arrival of further doses, other priority groups, including older people and those with health issues, which put them at higher risk for severe illness, will be vaccinated against the coronavirus.'    https://archive.vn/5Y993
No change in policy.

'Director of the Vaccination Department of the National Center for Communicable Diseases reported that since February 23, when the vaccination campaign kicked off in Mongolia, a total of around 13,200 people have received the first dose of AztraZeneca vaccine against coronavirus until today, March 4, Montsame reports.  Among them, 9500 people are healthcare personnel, including members of the teams administering COVID-19 vaccine, and 2,600 people are the first responders against CVOID-19, such as police, emergency management and professional inspection officials.  ...  According to the Ministry of Health, people over 50s, people with disabilities, individuals with underlying medical conditions, such as those with cardiovascular diseases, diabetes and cancer, groups of individuals of ready reserve mobilization for COVID-19 vaccination and response measures, employees of strategically-important sectors, such as border employees and coal-hauling truck drivers and employees of all-levels of educational organizations are next in line to receive coronavirus vaccines.'    https://archive.ph/R3eIP

As of 22 March, '[a] total of 223,444 people received first dose of vaccine so far nationwide, including 218,400 people in Ulaanbaatar and 5,044 people in Umnugobi aimag, since the vaccination campaign launched on February 23, Montsame reports.  According to the WHO recommendations, 98 percent of healthcare workers and 99 percent of personnel of other organizations that are working in the frontline to fight the COVID-19 have been inoculated. In Ulaanbaatar, about 185,000 people aged 50-64 are currently eligible for the first dose, of whom 19.5 percent have been inoculated. In addition, people over the age of 65 and those who had the transplants started receiving the first dose on March 22.'    https://archive.vn/De3Yz
No change in policy.

'Mongolia on Friday [i.e. 9 April 2021] received the first batch of COVID-19 vaccines it has purchased from China as part of the efforts to curb the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.  ...  Mongolia launched a COVID-19 vaccination campaign across the country on Feb. 23, and more than 323,600 people have been vaccinated so far, according to the country’s health ministry.  The country plans to vaccinate at least 60 percent of its 3.3 million people using four types of COVID-19 vaccines, and 20 percent will be vaccinated under COVAX, a global initiative for equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, said the ministry.'    https://archive.vn/z4jJd     Unclear which Chinese vaccine is received.

Mauritania began its COVID-19 vaccination campaign in late March as a shipment of 50,000 doses arrived from China.    President Mohamed Ould Ghazouani supervised the process, which took place in the National Hospital Centre in the capital Nouakchott.    According to the country's state news agency, Nouakchott's medical staff will get the jabs first, followed by medical staff in all other cities and people with chronic diseases and vulnerable groups. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406043506/https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20210326-mauritania-begins-covid-vaccine-campaign/

Dr Joomaye recalled that the Indian High-Commissioner, Mrs Nandini Singla, as well as the First Lady, Mrs Kobita Jugnauth, were among the first persons today to receive the COVAXIN vaccine at the Pandit Sahadeo Gymnasium in Vacoas. On 4th February, Co-Chairperson of the Presidential Taskforce on Covid-19 Dr John Phuka indicated in his daily situation update that Malawi "will roll out COVID-19 vaccination next month and the vaccine to be used is [the Oxford-AstraZeneca] vaccine", and reiterated that "it will target 20% of the population which include the frontline health workers and other social workers, the elderly and those with comorbidities"; and that "[such] preparations are at [the] advanced stage".  See Ministry of Health's Facebook post, archived at https://archive.vn/nX2PA    On 7th February, President Lazarus Chakwera announced during his Presidential Address on Covid that the country will receive 1.5 million doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine during its first consignment, expected to arrive at the end of February.  See the BBC's summary, archived at https://archive.vn/Tu5iy

Malawi received 360,000 doses of the AstraZeneca COVID vaccine on March 5 through the COVAX programme. "The Government of the Republic of Malawi has identified priority groups who will be among the first to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. These include health care workers, including those working in the private sector, who are at higher risk of COVID 19 infection than the general population due to the nature of their work, and more likely to be affected by COVID-19. Also included in phase one are police, immigration, Malawi Defence Force, teachers, prison warders, prisoners, those 60 years and above, and people with underlying conditions."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  The COVID 19 vaccine was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021 in Zomba and Mzuzu districts concurrently, presided over by the State President and Vice President respectively. As of 15 March, 890 health workers and other frontline workers have been vaccinated. Malawi aims to vaccinate 20% of its population in the initial vaccination phase through the COVAX initiative.  "On COVID-19 vaccination, let me inform the public that we are continuously working on  training more vaccination teams in the districts to ensure that more vaccination sites become  operational to increase access to the COVID-19 vaccine to the priority groups in the first  phase. As communicated on Thursday that, apart from continuing vaccinating the Health  Care Workers and other Social Workers, we rolled out vaccinating those with underlying  conditions (such as diabetes, asthma, hypertension) and those aged 60 years and above. It is important to note that the delivery platform remains the government and CHAM health facilities. The public is requested to contact their local/district health authorities for specific vaccination schedules for their area or district as more sites are being opened from tomorrow.  Let me request those coming for vaccination to bring their National Identity Cards while  those with underlying medical conditions to also remember to bring their health passport book (health profile). The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of  charge and that it is voluntary. In the spirit of Covax, the vaccine is being distributed to all  corners of the country to allow for equitable access. Let us all wait for our turn."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035053/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702864499769038    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035650/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702163413172480%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

"A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  COVID 19 vaccination was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021.   Ministry of Health update on march 26: ""I would like to commend the public for the overwhelming response to the call to get  vaccinated especially for those targeted in this first phase. The response gives hope to the  COVID-19 fight in our country. On the overall, the rolling out has been smooth although in  some vaccination sites, we observed long queues due to high numbers of people coming to get vaccinated against the available staff. There were also some information gaps in some communities especially in the rural areas. In view of this, the Government through the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 has allocated additional resources to assist in vaccination roll out. These resources will help to address the bottlenecks currently being observed. As we are working on these challenges, I would like to appeal for patience as we will ensure that everyone targeted in the first receives the vaccine.    Once again I would like to thank those that have made the excellent decision to get vaccinated. This is very commendable since fighting the COVID-19 pandemic is a collective effort. Let me also request those that are not eligible to receive the vaccine in the first phase, to patiently wait for their turn which will be communicated in due course. My request for those not eligible is to desist from going to the vaccination sites now to give opportunity to the elderly and those with co-morbidities to be vaccinated since COVID-19 tends to be more severe in these categories of people. The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of charge and that it is voluntary.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328193331/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3716961151692706%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328192921/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3720073904714764%3F__tn__%3DK-R

"A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. The government announced on March 29 that pregnant women are eligible for the vaccine. As of April 4, the government reports 157,581 distributed doses of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine. Local news reported that the ""government has ordered medical personnel to expedite the process of the Covid 19 vaccine in vaccination centres. It follows observations that the vaccination exercise is not starting at the set time of 8am in most centres due to delayed delivery of the vaccines. This has led to crowding and long queues, thereby raising security concerns and frustrating some people to get the vaccine. Currently, the vaccination exercise targets the elderly, people with underlying conditions, journalists and other social workers.""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404221016/https://www.nyasatimes.com/over-90-000-get-astrazeneca-jab-in-malawi/    April 4, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210404220051/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3746395888749232    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404215205/https://www.nyasatimes.com/govt-says-pregnant-women-can-now-get-vaccine/"

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. ""Currently, we are using the AstraZeneca vaccine and to get fully protected one is required to receive two doses at an interval of 8-12 weeks apart. Those that have received the first dose are encouraged to check on the vaccination card to see when their next dose is due.For those eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in the first phase i.e. the health workers, other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, please take note that the vaccination exercise is still in progress in all Government and CHAM facilities. Please take this opportunity to get vaccinated.""    April 5, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412001337/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3748838631838291

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  On April 6, the government announced that the vaccine is now available to everyone 18 years old and above. "I would like to inform the general public that we are now entering the second phase of COVID-19 vaccination whereby apart from those targeted in the first phase i.e. the health workers and other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, the vaccination has been extended to everyone aged 18 years and above. My special appeal goes to those who by nature of their occupation interact with a lot of people on daily basis such as those working in banks, shops, vendors and those in the transport sector to come and get the vaccine. I would like to request everyone aged 18 years and above to utilize this opportunity to get vaccinated so that they are protected from COVID-19 severe disease, risk of hospitalization or death due to COVID-19. The vaccination exercise continues in all the Government and CHAM health facilities."    April 6, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412000519/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3752144994840988    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411234712/https://www.nyasatimes.com/ministry-of-health-overwhelmed-with-turn-up-for-covid-19-vaccine/
https://archive.ph/1Sexi  Malawi's Ministry of Health expanded eligibility for the COVID-19 vaccine to all Malawians 18 and older.
No change in policy.

Namibia has made progress in preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines. The government has already paid an amount of N$29 272 320 (US$1 626 240) to acquire vaccine doses enough to vaccine 20% (508 200 persons) of the population through the COVAX Facility. The government has also signed a Financial Commitment Agreement on the 5th November 2020 for the remaining US$9 096 780. The Facility has informed us on the 6 January 2021 that it may be in a position to initiate a small scale “first wave” of deliveries using the Pfizer vaccine as early as end of January or February.  Apart from the COVAX Facility, there have been engagements with Pfizer on a bilateral basis, China, Russia, and other countries that are making great progress in the manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines for possible bilateral deals and or donations. We will prioritize frontline Health Care Workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19 disease once the vaccine become available.  Public education and community engagement on correct and authentic information about the vaccines is ongoing. The vaccine will save lives once it become available.    See "AMENDMENTS OF PUBLIC HEALTH COVID 19 GENERAL REGULATIONS: PUBLIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH ACT, 2015: DR KALUMBI SHANGULA, MP, MINISTER OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES. 23RD COVID-19 PUBLIC BRIEFING" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af), with announced measures set to take effect at 23:59 on January 13th, 2021.
No change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210124222442/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Daily+Update+22.01.2021.pdf/155c4bef-cd5d-4de3-b700-ff50b424b87e

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:   •	Has the government of Namibia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  No   •	According to Namibian Minister of Health and Social Services Kalumbi Shangula, Namibia has made progress in its preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines.  The government has paid to acquire enough vaccine doses to vaccine 20% of the population through the COVAX Facility.  Namibia may receive a small–scale “first wave” of vaccine deliveries as early as the end of January or February.  Additional resources need to be secured for acquisition of additional doses to vaccinate at least up to 60% of the population in order to achieve a desirable level of herd immunity.  Namibia will prioritize frontline health care workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19 once the vaccine becomes available.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163942/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There have been government announcements about preparations for the Pfizer vaccine and through the COVAX facility, but the specific details concerning vaccine delivery and administration are not clear.     See the president's 24th Covid-19 Public Briefing (https://web.archive.org/web/20210208145428/https://op.gov.na/documents/84084/1250033/Statement+by+Hage+G.+Geingob+on+the+Occasion+of+the+24th+COVID-19+Update%2C+3+Feb+2021.pdf/f3788ba0-646f-402d-9004-6c30fc37e48c). For reference, see also the announcement of previous government regulations from 13 January (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af).

The target populations include frontline health care workers, Community Health Workers, persons who are between 18 to 59 years, persons in close settings and those operating cross-border transportation, employees at Points of Entry, Police Officers,  Journalists, members of the diplomatic corps, Mining and fishery sector employees,  religious and traditional leaders, people with disability, minorities and refugees.     This is in accordance to Phase 1 of Namibia's vaccination plan and the vaccine administered is the Sinopharm SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine. Care professionals working in nursing homes, small-scale residential homes and disability care homes, district nurses and social support workers. A start was made in January 2021 on vaccinating the following groups: 1) Acute care hospital staff (staff working in intensive care units, A&E departments and on COVID-19 wards) and ambulance crews, who are directly involved in the care and treatment of COVID-19 patients; 2) Care professionals working in nursing homes, small-scale residential homes and disability care homes, district nurses and social support workers; 3) Nursing home residents and residents of homes for people with intellectual disabilities.  Vaccination is free and isn’t compulsory. Vaccines used are as following: BioNTech/Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Moderna, Janssen.   The government wants everyone over 18 to have had the opportunity to get at least 1 vaccine dose by early July, but the schedule could still change, for instance, if vaccine deliveries are delayed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403201637/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/getting-vaccinated-against-covid-19      https://web.archive.org/web/20210403201823/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/order-of-vaccination-against-coronavirus/factors-that-influence-the-vaccination-schedule

26/01/2021: In a joint press release from the New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Arden and  Minister for the COVID-19 Response Chris Hipkins stated that “We expect the first vaccines will arrive in New Zealand by the end of the first quarter but we are making sure everything is in place in case of an earlier arrival…We acknowledge that there is international pressures for Pfizer and BioNTech to prioritise countries that have serious community transmission of COVID-19. As we have seen, timelines are changing often.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129073244/https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/covid-19-vaccine-slated-possible-approval-next-week

"The Government has guaranteed that everyone in New Zealand will have access to the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. It has secured an additional 8.5 million doses, enough to vaccinate 4.25 million people."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318115418/https://covid19.govt.nz/health-and-wellbeing/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-vaccines-in-new-zealand/vaccines-being-used-in-new-zealand/      A- Key workers: "The first people to be vaccinated are people working at the border or in MIQ, and the people they live with (household contacts).    People in Group 1 can get early access to a vaccine because border and MIQ workers are most at risk of contracting COVID-19. Vaccinating this group first will also potentially reduce the risk of transmission in the community."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318115740/https://covid19.govt.nz/health-and-wellbeing/covid-19-vaccines/getting-a-covid-19-vaccine/how-our-vaccine-rollout-will-work/vaccine-rollout-groups/

A:    27 December  Dubai: Oman has launched a national COVID-19 vaccination campaign, with the sultanate’s health minister receiving the first dose of the Pfizer vaccine, local media reported.  State-run media reported that the first batch of 15,600 doses was flown in industrial freezers to Muscat International Airport last week to vaccinate a priority group of older adults, health care workers and those with underlying health conditions starting on Sunday (27 December).    The Health Ministry said the initial phase of the vaccination campaign would cover 20 percent of the population due to temporarily limited supply.    During the early stages of vaccine distribution, priority to develop immunity from COVID-19 will be given to those working on the frontline,” - therefore despite intentions to vaccinate more groups, have coded just one until further evidence emerges    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108103954/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/oman-launches-national-covid-19-vaccine-campaign-1.76136737     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118143949/https://www.hoteliermiddleeast.com/news/121645-oman-to-offer-covid-19-vaccine-from-december-27

Oman currently is on an inoculation drive with Pfizer as well as Astra Zeneca vaccines, with over 32 per cent of the population having received the shots as of February 24.    The first phase started with the coverage of frontline medical staff and among general population, those with immuno-compromised health above 65 years of age. As per the announcement by Dr. Saeedi, this week will see the start of vaccination for those who are 60 and above.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323092955/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/oman-covid-19-vaccine-for-ages-60-and-over-this-week-1.77492480

91,000 people in the country (57 per cent of the target groups) have already received the vaccinations. Around 30,000 people have received both doses, and 60,000 have been given a single dose so far. The country aims to receive 5.4 million doses of the vaccine by the end of this year. 30 per cent of Oman’s population will be given the coronavirus vaccine by the end of June, and 70 per cent by the end of 2021.   To date, the country has signed contracts to obtain 3.02 million doses of vaccines from multiple manufacturers: Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Johnson & Johnson’s. Negotiations with other companies will be made once they have reached the minimum requirements acceptable by international bodies. On 25 February, Health Secretary Francisco Duque said that Sinovac Biotech’s COVID-19 vaccine is safe and effective, citing assurances from the medical community.    The country expects to receive the first delivery of 600,000 doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines donated by the Chinese government.    It is also awaiting the delivery of 3.5 million doses of vaccines manufactured by AstraZeneca and Pfizer, through the COVAX Facility, a global alliance that seeks to help poor countries vaccinate their populations.    Galvez, who is also the chief implementer of the National Task Force Against COVID-19, reported that for the first quarter, the Philippines will receive a total of 5.1 million vaccine doses.    In the second quarter, a total of 24.1 million doses is expected to be delivered to the Philippines, which will come from COVAX and government procurements.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061146/https://pia.gov.ph/press-releases/releases/1067871

On 28 February, the 600,000 doses of Sinovac-made vaccines finally arrived in Manila on Sunday as part of China's commitment to supporting the Philippines' vaccination rollout.    The Chinese military plane carrying the donated vials called CoronaVac landed at the Villamor Airbase in Pasay City past 4 p.m. and was welcomed by several Cabinet members.    President Rodrigo Duterte also witnessed the historic event and inspected the crates containing the vials, the first-ever to arrive in the Philippines, during its ceremonial turnover to the Philippine government.    In his speech, Duterte thanked the Chinese government for the vaccine donation, confident that more batches of vaccines will be available at the earliest possible opportunity.    “I convey my sincere gratitude to the Chinese people and the government of China for this gesture of friendship and solidarity – the hallmark of Philippines-China partnership,” he said.    Duterte also reiterated his statement that Covid-19 vaccines should be treated as a global public good and made available to all, rich and poor alike    “No nation – no people - should be left to suffer the ravages of this pandemic for whatever reason," he said.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061604/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1132107

A (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Dr. Edwin Miraflor, officer-in-charge of the City Health Office (CHO) in Manila, said the first batch of vaccinees who took the second dose were among those who initially received the vaccines on March 5 and 7. Data from the CHO showed that some 5,452 medical front-liners here have been inoculated against Covid-19 as of March 31. Of the number, 3,095 received Sinovac while 2,357 were given Astra Zeneca.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406002735/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135808

A, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Announced March 28, Philippine will begin vaccinating the elderly alongside healthcare workers. The country has so far received 525,600 doses of AstraZeneca vaccines through the World Health Organization-led COVAX Facility. Apart from AstraZeneca vaccines, the country has also so far got 1 million doses Sinovac’s CoronaVac vaccine donated by Chinese government.  The national government’s vaccine priority list are as follows: A1 refers to frontline medical workers, A2 refers to senior citizens aged 60 and above, and A3 refers to persons with comorbidities.    In addition, President Duterte has announced Philippine will allow private companies to import COVID-19 vaccines "at will" in order to vaccinate their workers, in addition to those secured by the government provided the orders follow guidelines and are approved by the National Task Force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003259/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135144  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329072412/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135197    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003846/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/govt-allows-private-firms-to-import-covid-19-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330095530/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135371

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): In press briefing with the Presidential Spokesperson of Philippine, "as of April 3, 2021, 795,320 people have been vaccinated with the first dose of COVID-19 vaccines at 2,669 vaccination sites in the country. Of this number, 765,871 are frontline health care workers. Vaccination has also begun for senior citizens and individuals with comorbidities. A total of 16,121 grandparents were vaccinated in NCR and Region IV-A, while 13,328 were vaccinated against individuals with comorbidity."    The Philippines aims to secure 148 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines from several companies to inoculate an initial 50 to 70 million Filipinos this year. The bulk of vaccine doses are expected to arrive by the second and third quarters of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004822/https://pcoo.gov.ph/press-briefing/press-briefing-with-presidential-spokesperson-harry-roque-12/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004846/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135813

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): The Department of Health (DOH) on April 8 adopted the recommendation of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to temporarily suspend the use of AstraZeneca vaccines for individuals aged below 60 years old, following reports of rare cases of blood clots with low platelets detected in some individuals inoculated with the vaccine.  To date, the National Adverse Events Following Immunization Committee has not received any local reports of such side effects.  The NTF and the DOH reiterated that vaccination is safe and free. Senior citizens and persons with comorbidities are urged to receive the available vaccines from their local government units.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412034914/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136165

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Directed by the government of Philippines, local government units are further enjoined to prioritize the generation of the demand for vaccination to those with highest risk for severe disease and death, particularly Priority Groups A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities).  Use of AstraZeneca on persons under 60 continues to be suspended.    500,000 more doses of Sinovac vaccines arrived on Sunday afternoon from Beijing.  Jabs from Russia's Gamaleya Research Institute and US firm Moderna will arrive this month while deals with Pfizer-Biotech are ongoing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412031525/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210410-IATF-RESOLUTION-109-A.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412035821/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136401

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Priority Groups A1 (frontline medical workers), A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities) continue to be prioritized for vaccinations.  When there is sufficient supply of vaccines, Priority Group A4 (essential workers) will be able to get vaccinated simultaneously with the previous 3 groups. A4 Essential workers include: members of the media, basic education personnel, government workers, and economic frontliners.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233202/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136850  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233523/http://www.radyopilipinas.ph/rp-one/articles/national/a4-catergory-sa-pagbabakuna-posible-nang-simulan-sa-oras-na-madagdagan-ang-mga-bakuna-sa-bansa

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

Portugal has announced that it is suspending the inoculation of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine as a “precaution,” joining other European countries – including France, Germany, Italy and Spain – in halting its use following reports of blood clots post inoculation.    “Portuguese health authorities today decided to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine against Covid-19 for reasons of precaution and public health,” Portugal’s national health authority said Monday in a statement.     According to the national health authority, the decision was taken “due to reports of the appearance of blood clots in vaccinated people.”    The decision comes despite assertions from the United Kingdom’s Joint Committee on Vaccinations and Immunizations (JCVI) that the vaccine has been “rigorously tested for safety.”     The European Medicines Agency (EMA) also said Monday that the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine outweigh the risks, adding that the number of people developing blood clots after vaccination does not seem to be higher than in the general population.    The agency said it would hold an emergency meeting on Thursday to advise on “any further actions that may need to be taken.”    Note: Despite this suspension, the three priority groups continue to be vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316142901/https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-03-16-21/h_4342ae241ec9a83567b7eabedfc3b111

The president of Infarmed, Rui Ivo, started by revealing that the experts made an analysis of the vaccine that shows that "the benefits are greater than the risks" (...)". The list of priorities for the second phase of the vaccination plan against covid-19 will be changed, if the proposal of the specialist committee of the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) is approved. The plan is to start vaccinating by age, using the criterion of decreasing age groups, but simultaneously including people with diseases associated with increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, and without age limit. A new “two-legged strategy that will run in parallel”, the DGS said this Thursday.  (...) In the second phase, which begins after the completion of the vaccination of the priority groups of the first phase, on April 11, as announced by the task force coordinator, this new strategy must be “adjusted in order to vaccinate the largest number of people in the smallest period of time ”and taking into account“ an expected increase in the doses of vaccines available.".  Source: https://archive.vn/QtcHO

On 2 February, the Palestinian MoH launched its vaccination campaign in the West Bank, following the donation of 12,000 doses of the Modena and Sputnik V vaccines, giving priority to frontline health workers in ICUs. On 15 February, the MoH announced that it had to delay a broader rollout of the vaccination campaign, due to delays in anticipated deliveries.    In Gaza, the first batch of vaccines, 2,000 doses of Sputnik V, arrived on 17 February; an additional 20,000 does of Sputnik V were delivered on 21 February, as a donation from the United Arab Emirates. The vaccination campaign in Gaza began on 22 February, targeting frontline health workers.    The first vaccines delivered through the Gavi COVAX AMC Facility, in partnership with WHO and UNICEF, are now expected to arrive in March, including 37,400 doses of Pfizer/BioNTech, subject to agreement with the manufacturers. A further allocation of 240,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZenica vaccine are also expected, probably in June.    Through COVAX, the Palestinian Authority PA is eligible to receive donor funded COVID-19 vaccines for up to 20 percent of its population and has applied for additional doses to cover an additional 40 per cent of the population on a self-financing basis. According to the World Bank(link is external), about US$55 million will be needed to vaccinate 60 per cent of Palestinians, of which there is an existing gap of $30 million.    Israel is continuing its vaccination programme, which is also available to Palestinians in East Jerusalem, and currently ranks first globally for per capita vaccinations(link is external), with over three and a half million people already vaccinated with the first dose. On 23 February, Israel opened a vaccination centre at Qalandiya checkpoint for Palestinians with Israeli residency (from East Jerusalem) who live beyond the Barrier, and who face problems in accessing the remainder of Jerusalem city.    On 28 February, the Israeli government approved a plan to vaccinate over 120,000 Palestinians without Israeli residency, who are employed in Israel or in Israeli settlements, to be implemented at border crossings and in industrial zones across the West Bank. A number of Israeli, Palestinian and international health and human rights organizations, as well as Israeli health officials, have called on(link is external) the Israeli authorities to ensure that vaccines are equally and fairly provided to Palestinians living under occupation in the West Bank and Gaza.    https://archive.vn/HQxN3

C,B,A:  Per the Ministry of Public Health, vaccinations are prioritized for Older People (defined as over 60), people with sever chronic conditions (inc. diabetes, asthma, heart disease, compromised immune systems), and healthcare workers at higher risk of exposure. Details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210118165327/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Covid19-Vaccine/Pages/Priority-groups.aspx

Everyone is at risk of getting COVID-19 and developing serious complications from the virus, but certain population groups are at higher risk and it is therefore more important for these groups to receive the vaccine as soon as it is available.     Initially, vaccines will be prioritized for three key population groups: older people, people with certain chronic conditions and key healthcare workers.    Older people   Evidence from both here in Qatar and around the world clearly shows that the risk of developing severe complications due to COVID-19 increases with age. People over 60 years of age have a higher risk of severe illness and death.     People with severe chronic conditions   People with certain long-term chronic medical conditions, including diabetes, asthma, and heart disease, or compromised immune systems, have an increased risk of developing severe complications as a result of COVID-19, regardless of their age.     Healthcare workers at high risk of exposure to COVID-19?    Healthcare workers, especially doctors, nurses and paramedics working directly with COVID-19 patients, have an increased risk of being exposed to COVID-19 and catching the virus and becoming sick. Additionally, healthcare workers who catch the virus can spread it to their patients, many of whom may be at increased risk of severe complications due to chronic conditions or compromised immune systems. ??  /web/20210209193238/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Covid19-Vaccine/Pages/Priority-groups.aspx
Along with Pfizer-BioNTech jab reserves already being administered. Qatar has also approved emergency use of Moderna’s vaccines, https://archive.vn/r1ivX

At the proposal of the Ministry of Health, the Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/KYZQL

A:    The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population. On 27th of December, the first stage started with the first 10 000 doses of vaccines in all 10 infectious disease hospitals on the front lines in the fight against COVID-19.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL, https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh and https://archive.fo/wip/pnsuB

As of 20 February, stage 2 of the vaccination campaign against COVID is ongoing. Vaccines are provided at no cost to the individual.     Between 18 February at 17:00 and 19 February at 17:00, 28,019 Pfizer vaccines, 671 Moderna vaccines, and 9,438 AstraZeneca vaccines were administered.    Stage 2 includes adults over the age of 65; persons with chronic diseases, regardless of age, according to the indications of the vaccines used; persons with a degree of disability, immobilized persons, immunocompromised persons, their companions and persons living in the same household with them; homeless people; essential workers.    On 20 February, the coordinator of the vaccination campaign against COVID, military doctor Valeriu Gheorghita, said that stage 3 of the vaccination campaign could start in April, and registration would start in March.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222235341/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/actualizare-zilnica-19-02-evidenta-persoanelor-vaccinate-impotriva-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222235113/https://www.digi24.ro/stiri/actualitate/sanatate/valeriu-gheorghita-a-anuntat-cand-va-incepe-vaccinarea-persoanelor-din-etapa-a-iii-a-1455320?__grsc=cookieIsUndef0&__grts=53801262&__grua=915fe5f49a696a6a12f1f7d93c029921&__grrn=1    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201234335/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/vaccinarea-sars-cov-2/procesul-de-vaccinare-in-romania/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210223000515/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/resurse/intrebari-si-raspunsuri/

Statement from 11 December:  Mikhail Mishustin: “We are opening the first vaccination stations. In December, the Federation’s constituent entities will receive 480,000 vaccine doses. I would like to ask the regional authorities to see to it that vaccination stations are open during the New Year holidays, between 1 and 10 January, so that anybody who wants to can be vaccinated. [...] I would like to remind everyone that vaccination must be voluntary and absolutely free.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214035225/http://government.ru/en/news/41092/

All regions now ready for vaccination. The vaccination started in Moscow on 5 December. No overall clear policy found.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104133348if_/http://government.ru/en/search/?q=coronavirus&dt.till=04.01.2021&dt.since=7.05.2012&sort=rel&type=
No clear policy found despite vaccination in progress.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104100018/http://government.ru/en/news/

C:    Vaccination against COVID-19 has started in Moscow. The City Government is regularly extending the groups of residents who can sign up for vaccination. Currently, these groups include:    Muscovites over 60 (they are at the highest risk of severe COVID-19 and complications);  People with chronic conditions who are required to stay at home during the pandemic;  College and university students aged 18 and older.    Also, people aged 18 and over who work in the following fields and organisations can get vaccinated. In the future, it will be available to all Moscow residents.    As this is not yet available across all of Russia, I have coded this as a 1 for group C elderly groups, until more evidence emerges that this is accessible country wide    http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

C:  Sputnik V  On 17 January, the mass free and voluntarily vaccination against COVID-19 was launched. The jab is now available to everyone, not only people in the risk groups.     Since this article also discusses regional variability and producing enough vaccine, for now, keeping as a single group until there is further evidence more groups are able to vaccinate broadly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131231130/http://government.ru/en/news/41349/

From 18 January 2021, Russia launched a mass vaccination policy for free. Everyone 18+can receive a vaccine on a voluntary basis. It should be mentioned that during December only elderly people, medical workers, and people with chronic diseases had an opportunity to receive vaccines. Now, there are no such restrictions. Since the vaccination on a voluntary basis and the number of people to get vaccinated only increasing.      Links: https://archive.vn/kmTXE https://archive.vn/jkeWX https://archive.vn/qTPC4 https://archive.vn/0s2lb
