RIYADH: Almost 300,000 people have received the COVID-19 vaccine in Saudi Arabia, the health ministry said on Sunday.  “The vaccine is the key and the powerful weapon that will make us healthy,” ministry spokesperson Dr. Mohammed Al-Abd Al-Aly said.  He said citizens and residents who have a valid national identity number or residence number are eligible to receive the vaccine through the “Sehaty” app.   /web/20210209002245/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1794306/saudi-arabia

On November 11, the authorities announced that Saudi has signed an agreement to receive early supplies of 3 vaccines. On December 10, the authorities approved the registration of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Registration for free vaccination began on December 15 and inoculation started on December 17. On January 19, 2021, AstraZeneca and Moderna vaccines were approved for use in Saudi Arabia in addition the previously approved Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine:  https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#S

The Kingdom’s aim is to make the COVID-19 vaccine available to all citizens and residents within the coming months, based on a phased strategic plan to limit the impact the COVID-19 virus on our community and our critical infrastructure. To that end, the targeted population for each phase of the roll-out have been identified based on specific criteria selected by the MOH and the Saudi CDC.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210318003002/https://www.moh.gov.sa/en/awarenessplateform/VariousTopics/Pages/COVID-19Vaccine.aspx

RIYADH: Saudi Arabia’s Ministry of Health announced it is expanding its coronavirus (COVID-19) inoculation campaign to reach a wider segment of society.  The ministry said that the registered priority groups have been covered and it will make vaccinations available to other groups.  There are plans to launch more vaccination centers across all regions of the Kingdom, with the cooperation of public and private health service providers.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210324213316/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1823451/saudi-arabia    More than seven million people have been vaccinated against the coronavirus disease in Saudi Arabia, the Ministry of Health announced on Sunday.  For more coronavirus news, visit our dedicated page.  Over 587 vaccination centers have opened across the Kingdom to ensure all citizens and residents have easy access to the dose, according to the ministry.    Last month, the Kingdom announced it would be expanding its national coronavirus vaccine campaign to include a much larger segment of its population.  The registered priority groups have all received their COVID-19 vaccines, which is why the ministry has now made the dose available to other groups of people.  Individuals who wish to be vaccinated must first register on the official Sehhaty application.  They can then book direct appointments according to the available dates and the nearest vaccination center, according to the health ministry.  “This step comes as a continuation of health efforts to preserve the safety of citizens and residents and limit the spread of COVID-19 and facilitate vaccination,” the health ministry had said at the time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418035700/https://english.alarabiya.net/coronavirus/2021/04/18/More-than-7-mln-people-in-Saudi-Arabia-received-COVID-19-vaccine-Ministry-

However, it may also be relevant to consider these workers in terms described by the Minister of Health as those "who are in jobs or settings where risk of a super-spreading event is high" (see M1, 2nd February for link)    "Front-line workers in the aviation and maritime sectors started getting jabs on Jan 13 as part of an operational trial, before the mass exercise began in earnest on Jan 18. He told reporters he is confident that a substantial number of workers from the aviation and maritime sectors will be fully vaccinated by the end of the month."    http://archive.today/2021.02.12-202659/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/first-flights-with-fully-vaccinated-crew-depart-singapore-in-milestone-for-sia

Groups: A,C    Singapore Ministry of Health Announcement 19TH FEB 2021           We are making good progress in our vaccination efforts. As of 18 February 2021, about 250,000 individuals have received their first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Amongst them, more than 110,000 have also received their second dose of the vaccine, and completed the full vaccination regimen. Following the successful pilots in Ang Mo Kio and Tanjong Pagar, we will commence COVID-19 vaccinations for seniors in the community from 22 February.    3.    COVID-19 vaccination for seniors will commence island-wide from 22 February. Over the next three weeks, seniors aged 70 years and above can expect to receive personalised letters inviting them to sign up for vaccination. We will start by inviting seniors living near polyclinics or vaccination centres, so that they can be conveniently vaccinated at a vaccination site near their home. By mid-March when we have opened a vaccination centre in each town, all seniors will be able to receive their vaccination. We expect all the letters to reach our seniors aged 70 years and above by the first week of March.    4.    Thereafter we will move to vaccinate the seniors aged 60 to 69 years. They will receive their invitation letters around the middle of March, and the vaccination will commence from around end-March onwards.    8.   To ensure that seniors can conveniently receive their vaccinations, we will set up more vaccination centres in the coming weeks. Currently, there are 11 vaccination centres in operation[3]. Three more vaccination centres located at community centres/clubs will commence operations by 22 February, at Bukit Timah, Marine Parade and Taman Jurong, bringing the total to 14. By the middle of March, 31 vaccination centres will be in operation, with at least one vaccination centre in each town. In total, there will eventually be around 40 vaccination centres, with each vaccination centre planned for an estimated capacity of 2,000 vaccinations per day.    http://archive.today/2021.02.22-144640/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/start-of-covid-19-vaccination-for-seniors    Coding note: the code for H7 was previously changed from 1G to 2G on 27th January in response to the pilot vaccination programme for elderly groups at Ang Mo Kio and Tanjong Pagar.

"    http://archive.today/2021.02.26-142510/https://www.lta.gov.sg/content/ltagov/en/newsroom/2021/2/news-releases/COVID-19_vaccinations_for_active_taxi_and_private_hire_car_drivers.html

Groups "A,C:"    Article below from MOH provides overview of vaccine prioritisation.  Notes vaccination of elderly groups (>70 years old) began on 22nd February and will extend to those over 60 years old later this month.  The second group consists of health workers and those in critical roles (e.g. security agencies and those responsible for utilities).  Other groups mentioned are those where there is higher risk of transmission (e.g. those who work in markets and in educational establishments.  Migrant workers living in dormitories are also mentioned with a plan to vaccinate 10,000 who have "never been infected by Covid 19 and are living in the five largest dormitories".  Finally it refers to "selected cargo drivers and accompanying personnel who enter Singapore from Malaysia on a regular basis".      The article ends: "We will continue to systematically extend the vaccination to other segments from April onwards. All Singaporeans and long-term residents in Singapore will have the chance to be vaccinated. "    Coding note: Group C (Elderly Groups) and Group A (Key workers) are clearly referred to in the policy.  The reference to "Higher Risk Groups" in this article does not appear to refer to Group B (Clinically Vulnerable Groups), but rather to individuals who are at higher risk of exposure to Covid-19 and the article makes no clear reference to Group B.    http://archive.today/2021.03.08-181420/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/covid-19-vaccination-brought-forward-for-all-seniors-extended-to-essential-services-personnel-and-higher-risk-groups

Straits Times article with useful summary of the timeline and groups for vaccination strategy:    8th Jan: healthcare workers  11th jan: Home Team Officers  13th Jan: Singapore Airlines staff  14th Jan: Armed Forces  18th Jan: frontline workers in aviation and maritime sectors  27th Jan: pilot for seniors aged >70  22nd Feb: roll out of vaccines for all seniors aged > 70  23rd Feb: taxi and private hire drivers    Over the coming weeks, vaccination policy will be extended to:  Postal staff  Delivery staff  Reporters  Critical bank operation staff  Hawker stall holders and assistants  Teachers / staff in schools  Migrant workers in dormitories  Cargo drivers coming from Malaysia    As noted on 8th March, although the policy is expanding, no specific mention is made of "group B "Clinically vulnerable groups".  It is coded as "2" (Two groups) referring to groups A and C taking a wide definition of "Keyworkers" although it is relevant to note that the expansion of the policy mentions those at high risk of coming into contact/spreading the virus rather than being Keyworkers per se.    http://archive.today/2021.03.12-174255/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/singapores-covid-19-vaccination-drive-brought-forward-for-all-seniors-extended-to

Groups: A,C: (also see previous notes and note below suggesting that vaccine rollout is extending beyond groups A and C.  Code of "3" is not warranted as no reference has been found to Group B, and code "4" is also not applicable as the vaccine is not "broadly available".  Hence decision to leave code as "2")    Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer (see note below)    MOH Press Release: highlights the increase in numbers of vaccine centres and the vaccines currently in use:    "Four of the seven upcoming vaccination centres will administer the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine. These four vaccination centres are at Hong Kah North Community Club, Marsiling Community Club, Punggol 21 Community Club and Radin Mas Community Club. The other vaccination centres, polyclinics and selected PHPCs will continue to offer the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine. As more supplies of the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine arrive, more vaccination centres will offer the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine."    http://archive.today/2021.03.22-144711/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/more-vaccination-centres-nationwide-with-the-roll-out-of-the-moderna-vaccine    Straits Times Article: "Singapore residents under 'exceptional circumstances' can apply for early Covid-19 vaccination"    http://archive.today/2021.03.22-150521/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/those-who-need-to-travel-overseas-for-urgent-work-study-or-medical-reasons-can-apply-for

Groups: A,C + others  Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer    Policy update from Ministry of Health    Key points:  a) Vaccine roll out  - As of 23 March 1.1 million doses of vaccine have been administered and almost 800,000 citizens have received at least one dose.  - Vaccination of adults over 70 began on 22nd February  - Vaccination of adults 60 and over was initiated in mid march  - Adults aged 45-59 can now register for vaccination    Coding note: the vaccination policy has now widened out to include those aged 45 and over but is not widely available to those under 45 years of age.  No reference is made to clinically vulnerable groups.  The code is therefore unchanged at "2".    http://archive.today/2021.03.26-165024/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-vaccination-programme-further-easing-of-community-measures

Parliamentary Q&A Highlights: Update on Vaccination Programme    Vaccination is free for all Singaporeans and long term residents  By mid-April there will be 40 vaccination centres  Supply of vaccines remains limited due to global demand and ability of vaccine manufacturers to deliver  Prioritisation has been healthcare workers, vulnerable elderly and those involved in Covid-19 operations.  Also those of critical importance and with higher risk of exposure.  60% of those over 70, 70% of those aged 60-69 and 17% of those aged 45-59 have received vaccine or booked appointment.     Vaccinations for those under 45 are expected to commence in June  Since March 15th citizens who wish to receive vaccine early if they are due to travel may do so provided they meet certain criteria.    http://archive.today/2021.04.09-180356/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-covid-19-vaccination-programme-parl

Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer   Groups: "A,C"    There continues to be no reference to Group B "clinically vulnerable groups" other than "vulnerable elderly" citizens in the Parliamentary Q&A    Currently vaccination programme is rolled out to those above age 45, to others in critical roles and/or at high risk of exposure.  There is also an option for some to get vaccine early if they are travelling outside the country on compassionate grounds or for work or study provided they meet official criteria.    Singapore expects to vaccinate the population by end 2021.    http://archive.today/2021.04.09-180356/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-covid-19-vaccination-programme-parl

The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021. On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures. As of 24 November, the Slovak Republic is part of “Team Europe” and has joined COVAX. Therefore, once vaccines are available it is expected that the following policy will be in place:  The Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunizations, through the COVAX platform ensures coverage of 20% of the country's population free of charge, the following target groups have been identified: medical workers; adults over 65 years of age and comorbidities (high risk group); beneficiaries of temporary or long-term placement centers; people with comorbidities; social workers; workers in the field of education and those in security bodies. A:    On 26 December, the first person received a vaccine and roll-out out 4 additional hospitals was scheduled to begin 27 December. Four waves of vaccination are planned:  1. healthcare staff, employees of nursing homes, critical infrastructure;  2. people older than 65 years, people suffering from chronic diseases, clients of nursing homes;  3. marginalised groups, homeless people, asylum seekers, teachers;  4. everybody older than 18 years (voluntary principle).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214442/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22562138/vaccines-have-arrived.html

A:    No policy changes, workers in health care / social services are eligible to sign-up for vaccination currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109223845/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=frontpage&Itemid=1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html

A,C:    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna    As of 05 February, it was expected to add AstraZeneca in the following week. In addition, the Health Ministry is considering ordering the Russian-made Sputnik V vaccine.     https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22590217/news-digest-british-variant-widespread-across-the-country.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206212305/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22589821/should-people-be-able-to-choose-their-vaccine-its-better-not-to-say-experts-and-ministry.html?ref=av-center

Another group to be vaccinated are people suffering from serious diseases, regardless of their age, as well as carers and people entitled to care benefits. After this group is vaccinated, people with moderately serious diseases will be next, regardless of age.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419222924/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22594546/vaccination-strategy-changes-again-teachers-will-receive-the-jab-sooner-than-planned.html

Sputnik V will be examined by the State Institute for Drug Control. Vaccines of Pfizer/BioNTech, Astra Zeneca and Moderna are used.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301190755/https://spectator.sme.sk/r/25/politics-and-society.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301144631/https://korona.gov.sk/

People older than 50 years may sign up for vaccination with the AstraZeneca vaccine.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419220917/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22627088/vaccination-opened-for-another-age-group.html

People above 40 are allowed to get vaccinated since 13 April. This is due to a low innoculation rate of seniors (who show low interest in the vaccination).    vaccines: Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Johnson&Johnson    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419214001/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22639411/warnings-sounded-over-low-vaccination-uptake-among-elderly.html?ref=av-left

No changes found  Links -   https://web.archive.org/web/20201221103126/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221103232/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A, C:    "Residents and employees of homes for the elderly who have not been infected with SARS-CoV-2 will be vaccinated first, with the aim of vaccinating as many residents and employees of homes for the elderly as possible."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210109015041/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-12-26-first-batch-of-vaccine-arrives-in-slovenia/    "Vaccination will be free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210110171517/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19

A, C:    "Slovenia received a second batch of vaccines, 6,825 doses, which will mostly be used to vaccinate healthcare workers in hospitals."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210110171805/https://www.gov.si/novice/2020-12-30-v-sloveniji-ze-druga-posiljka-cepiva-proti-covid-19-cepivo-je-ucinkovito-in-varno/

A, C:  The vaccination campaign continues, with the priority given to those over 85 and the remainder going to health workers.  The Pfizer vaccine is being used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118212237/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-01-13-rise-in-hospital-admissions/

Pfizer/BionTech & Moderna & AstraZeneca vaccines     The vaccination of people older than 80 continues throughout the country today, including in Ljubljana and Ajdovšcina.    Vaccination is free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured or not. Funds for the purchase of vaccines and costs for vaccination are provided in the budget of the Republic of Slovenia.    5 Feb -  Slovenia started vaccinating the elderly in care homes first, as care homes recorded frequent outbreaks and suffered the most fatalities. Apart from the elderly, nursing home and hospital staff are also being vaccinated in Slovenia at the moment.    The country has also recently received the first batch of a vaccine developed by AstraZeneca, which is, however, recommended for a younger population.       Link: https://archive.vn/cwvre  https://archive.vn/OFLYU  https://archive.vn/hH21B
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/cjyI0

Per Slovenian government announcement, vaccination administration has begun with health care workers and vulnerable populations. According to the announcement, when general distribution is possible, vaccines will be available to all residents of Slovenia (but not visitors), regardless of insurance status:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210318000619/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Per Slovenian government announcement, vaccination administration began with health care workers, critical infrastructure workers, and vulnerable populations. For the general population, Slovenia is currently vaccinating those age 60+.  According to the announcement, vaccines are available to all residents of Slovenia (but not visitors), regardless of insurance status. Following vaccines are administered: Astra-Zenica, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech.   Vaccination is free of charge and provided to all who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia and not only for citizens of the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.      https://archive.vn/L16sj  https://archive.vn/ATjR8

A, C:    The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. During Phase 1, which started on 27 December, elderly living in care homes or receive home care under the Social Services Act, staff working directly with these people, and adults living with someone belonging to this risk group are eligible. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

A,C:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Phase 2: Next, vaccination will be offered to those 65 years old and above. This includes adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219213752/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    The vaccinations are carried out by the regions, so the phase of the vaccination programme can differ from region to region. Currently, some regions are in phase 1 and some in phase 2:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219213335/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-information-about-coronavirus    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219214611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/tredje-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-har-godkants    The government recommends AstraZeneca only for people under 65: https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211851/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/februari/astra-zenecas-vaccin-rekommenderas-till-personer-under-65-ar/    Vaccinations still taking place:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219212151/https://www.thelocal.se/20210129/charts-how-is-swedens-vaccination-programme-going

Rather, two groups seems more accurate at the naional level as an average.     Previous coding note:   A,B,C:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Phase 2: Next, vaccination will be offered to those 65 years old and above. This includes adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226205411/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    The vaccinations are carried out by the regions, so the phase of the vaccination programme can differ from region to region. Some regions are still at the stage of vaccinating only people in nursing homes, some regions vaccinate 80+, some 70+, some 65+. From 2 March onwards, several regions have started announcing that they are in phase 2, which includes a few clinically vulnerable groups: adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308222627/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219214611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/tredje-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-har-godkants    Vaccinations are still taking place: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308223138/https://www.thelocal.se/20210129/charts-how-is-swedens-vaccination-programme-going/

Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311193915/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn  Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311191515/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca https://web.archive.org/web/20210219214611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/tredje-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-har-godkants    The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only next month:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311194318/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/statistik/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

A,C:   Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy: http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191115/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191447/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna  - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/   - On 16 March, the use of AstraZeneca was suspended until the European Medicines Agency (EMA) had completed its investigation of suspected side effects such as bleeding and blood clots.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191331/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/astra-zenecas-vaccin-pausas-som-en-forsiktighetsatgard-i-vantan-pa-emas-utredning/      Vaccinations are still taking place:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210319191720/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

In addition to the note added to the entry for 16 March:  On 18 March, the European Medicines Agency announced that the benefits outweigh the risks fort he use of AstraZeneca, but Sweden continued to halt the use of AstraZeneca because the Swedish Public Health Agency had not yet taken position.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210319190317/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fortsatt-paus-for-vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-i-avvaktan-pa-beslut/

Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. The Public Health Agency is still interpreting EMA’s safety review after new information came out, but it announced on 8 April that in the process, its approach will remain to use AstraZeneca for people over 65 only: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409195713/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/bedomning-pagar-efter-utlatande-fran-europeiska-lakemedelsmyndigheten-ema/     - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194534/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

On 8 April, the region of Uppsala announced it would give people who had already had Covid-19 a single dose of the vaccine, six months after infection: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194714/https://www.thelocal.se/20210408/uppsala-to-offer-only-one-dose-of-vaccine-to-people-who-have-had-covid-19/

On 9 April, Uppsala reversed its decision to only give previously infected people only 1 dose of the vaccine: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194722/https://www.thelocal.se/20210409/swedish-region-makes-u-turn-on-new-covid-19-vaccination-rules/

A,B,C:  Almost all regions are now in phase 2, a few still in phase 1, and Kalmar is the first region to have entered phase 3.     Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.  Phase 3 in Kalmar initially means everyone over 60, and later will also include over-18s who have certain underlying health conditions, including chronic heart, lung, liver or kidney disease, severe asthma, diabetes, health conditions that cause impaired lung functioning (for example extreme obesity, neuromuscular diseases or multiple disabilities), Down syndrome, or people with a severely weakened immune system due to illness or ongoing medical treatment.     Information on phases:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419192822/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   - http://web.archive.org/web/20210419200401/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  - http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194247/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset  - Kalmar press release: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419200726/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/60-64-aringar-kan-boka-vaccination/     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - From 25 March, the use of AstraZeneca was continued for people over 65, but remained suspended for younger people: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-kan-fortsatta-for-personer-som-ar-65-ar-och-aldre/  - Re Janssen: The American manufacturer has suspended deliveries of Janssen's vaccine to Europe. To date, 31,000 doses have arrived in Sweden, but none have been distributed for vaccination. The Swedish Public Health Agency is now awaiting the results of the EMA's ongoing safety investigation. Until then, the recommendation is not to use the vaccine doses: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419193234/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/janssens-vaccin-pausas-i-vantan-pa-utredning-fran-ema/     Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419192826/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

Eswatini has joined the COVAX Facility through which the country will secure vaccine doses to cover 20 percent of the population, of which 108,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine are expected in early March, and the remaining balance will arrive in 2021Q2. Government has further ordered 2 million doses from the Serum Institute of India and 237,328 doses from the AU, both expected to arrive in 2021Q2. The Eswatini National Immunization Technical Advisory Group (ESWANITAG) was appointed to provide scientific recommendations during the introduction of new vaccines and the implementation of immunization strategies.  In FY21/22 the government has budgeted E200 million to procure vaccines for Eswatini's entire population.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322074813/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Rollout of COVID vaccination campaign. Currently in phase 1 of the programme, targeting frontline health workers (group A). The vaccine administered is AstraZeneca. A: healthcare workers.  Oxford/Astrazeneca    Dushanbe, Tajikistan, 09 March 2021 – Today Tajikistan received via the COVAX Facility, 192,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine. This is the first shipment of COVID-19 vaccines from the COVAX Facility to arrive in Central Asia and the second such shipment to the WHO European Region.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210316210247/https://www.unicef.org/tajikistan/press-releases/tajikistan-becomes-first-country-central-asia-receive-covid-19-vaccine-through-0

Plans for vaccination campaigns have been announced and doses have been received by Tajikistan but are only supposed to begin in mid-2021.    ______________________________________  Quote from article 1:  "Dushanbe, Tajikistan, 09 March 2021 – Today Tajikistan received via the COVAX Facility, 192,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford COVID-19 vaccine."    Archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134037/https://www.unicef.org/tajikistan/press-releases/tajikistan-becomes-first-country-central-asia-receive-covid-19-vaccine-through-0    ______________________________________  Quote from article 2:  "The COVID-19 vaccines will be provided through the Gavi-COVAX Advanced Market Commitment Global Financing Mechanism (for about 16 percent of the population) and through this project (4 percent). The procurement and delivery of vaccines will be undertaken by UNICEF. The Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Population of Tajikistan (MoHSP) has identified the segments of the populations that will be included in the first stage of the vaccination program, including health and social care workers, the population over 50 years of age, people with underlying health conditions, as well as teachers and employees of educational institutions.    The exact number of people to be vaccinated under this additional financing and in collaboration with COVAX, will depend on final vaccine prices negotiated between COVAX and manufacturers."    Archived link 2:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134057/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2021/02/11/world-bank-supports-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-tajikistan    ____________________________________    Quote from article 3:  "the Minister of Health said that the distribution of the first vaccines would begin by mid-2021.    According to him, following the instructions of the COVAX mechanism, first, it is necessary to ensure the vaccination of:    The healthcare and social workers who are at a high risk of infection,  The elderly and persons suffering from chronic non-contagious diseases, such as cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, diseases associated with metabolic disorders, or have a high risk of death.  The target group from the population to be vaccinated against COVID-19 is already determined: it is 1.8 million people or 20% of the population of Tajikistan. This group includes healthcare and education workers, persons over 50 and persons with chronic non-contagious diseases.    The vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge. After the vaccine is delivered to Tajikistan, the Ministry of Health of the country will announce the locations and the process of registering for vaccination."    Archived link 3:  http://archive.today/2021.03.22-134842/https://www.intellinews.com/tajikistan-receives-first-batch-of-covid-19-vaccines-205134/

Wednesday, July 22, 2020 - 21:17  The Pacific region, including Tonga, is requesting access to a vaccine currently being developed to fight COVID-19, said the Minister for Health Hon ‘Amelia Tu’ipulotu today. They are talking to the World Health Organisation and taking part in preliminary discussions with the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access (COVAX) Facility and GAVI, the Vaccine Alliance. It is hoped that by the end of 2021 there will be enough vaccine to immunise 20% of the population, starting with front line workers.    http://archive.today/2020.12.18-124633/https://matangitonga.to/2020/07/22/pacific-access-vaccine

"Tonga wants to join COVAX to access CoViD-19 vaccines Wednesday, August 26, 2020 - 19:44 Tonga has provided an Expression of Interest to join COVAX to access CoViD-19 vaccines confirmed the Ministry of Health CEO, Dr Siale ‘Akau’ola. It will give early access to vaccinations for the most vulnerable people in member countries populations."  http://archive.today/2020.12.18-130554/https://matangitonga.to/2020/08/26/tonga-wants-join-covax-access-covid-19-vaccines

"Covid-19 vaccine roll out starts in parts of the Pacific"    Vaccinations reported to be commencing in the US territory of the Northern Mariana Islands, but it remains unclear when other countries in the region will access vaccines.    "New Zealand now has agreements in place to secure enough vaccines to vaccinate everyone in the country, as well as everyone in Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, Tokelau, Niue, and the Cook Islands, if the governments of those countries accept the offer."      "Tonga working through WHO plan  Tongan Ministry of Health chief executive Dr Siale 'Akauola said the country had been working with development partners "for a long time" to prepare for the vaccines.  The kingdom had also applied to COVAC for vaccines, and was awaiting a response."    Dr Akauola also questions whether it will be feasible to use the Pfizer vaccine in Tonga given the requirements for low temperture storage.    http://archive.today/2020.12.20-100600/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/programmes/datelinepacific/audio/2018777662/covid-19-vaccine-roll-out-starts-in-parts-of-the-pacific

Currently the vaccine is unavailable but an announcement from COVAX is expected soon. The policy details (National Deployment and Vaccination Plan (NDVP)) are explained in this article.    Article notes that COVAX donates part of the vaccine and cold chain, but in order to increase coverage the countries must also contribute to the cost.  Tonga is in discussion with "development partners" to secure additional funding.    "Vaccine priority groups  Tonga’s plan is to prioritize frontline workers (those staff working/managing quarantine facilities, those required to respond to suspected cases, those working at port of entry and transporting repatriated passengers) to receive the vaccine first, followed by the elderly and those with chronic illnesses, explained Dr ‘Akau’ola.  The remaining adult population will follow. Children will be the last priority to be vaccinated."    Article notes COVAX "initial plan was to roll out CoViD-19 vaccines to frontline workers only for participant countries"    In the region, several countries have already received vaccines and are have started to implement their vaccination plans including: French Polynesia, Guam, New Caledonia, Marshall Is, American Samoa, FSM and Palau.    http://archive.today/2021.01.31-153157/https://matangitonga.to/2021/01/30/tonga-finalizing-plan-access-covid-19-vaccines

Article from Matangitonga online news:    Announcement on vaccine distribution from COVAX facility.  Refers to the distribution of vaccines in the first half of 2021 which will be followed by a further distribution later in the year.    Tonga nominally allotted 43,800 doses from AZ/SKBio manufacturing source.  However no precise date is given for when vaccines will arrive and article notes the number of doses may change.  (Context note: population of Tonga is in region of 100,000 people)    "The other 10 Pacific countries with indicative doses of AZ/SKBio are:    Fiji 100,800 doses;  Kiribati – 48,000;  Marshall Islands – 24,000;  Micronesia (Federated States of) – 48,000;  Nauru – 7,200;  New Zealand 249,600;  Samoa – 79,200;  Tonga – 43,200  Tuvalu – 4,800  Vanuatu 100,800.    The indicative distribution is intended to provide interim guidance to COVAX Facility participating countries to help their governments and public health leaders to plan and prepare for the first rounds of vaccine distribution this year, and a successful national roll out of vaccines.    “It is therefore non-binding and may be subject to change,” the forecast stated."    http://archive.today/2021.02.08-141121/https://matangitonga.to/2021/02/06/covax-facility-announces-vaccines-release-first-half-2021

TUNIS, Dec. 15 (Xinhua) -- The COVID-19 vaccines will be free for all Tunisian citizens, Hechmi Louzir, director general of the Pasteur Institute of Tunis, said on Tuesday.    Louzir told Tunis Afrique Presse that the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine will be allocated to those suffering from chronic diseases, the elderly, and health workers, adding that the vaccination will not be mandatory.    The health official affirmed that his country has already reserved 2 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines from the American pharmaceutical company Pfizer.    The Tunisian Ministry of Health has signed an agreement to obtain the above-mentioned vaccines at a price of seven U.S. dollars per dose.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111103217/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-12/16/c_139592399.htm    https://archive.vn/wip/c9LXn

The Minister of Health stressed that the solution to controlling the epidemic in the medium term is to provide vaccination, reminding that the aim of the vaccination campaign is to reduce serious cases and deaths, maintain the capacity of the health system and protect health personnel.    According to the national strategy for mers-CoV vaccination, priority groups have been identified: citizens over 60 years of age, health professionals and vital interests, under 60 years of age with chronic diseases.        The minister stressed that the vaccines will be free, effective and high quality as it was decided to acquire vaccines from various international laboratories that have finished their research and obtained the license, announcing that pfizer laboratory obtained yesterday the license to market In Tunisia, waiting for the rest of the laboratories to obtain distribution licenses in our country in the coming weeks.    https://archive.vn/alywx

On 28th of January, the vaccination of the citizens at the age of 75 and above was started with Chinese Sinovac vaccine from CoronoVac firm.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201020353/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/coronavirus-vaccination-in-turkey-begins-for-citizens-75-and-above/news

A,C:     On 11 February, health care workers, who were first to receive jabs last month, started receiving the second dose of CoronaVac. The inactive vaccine developed by China’s Sinovac is the only one available in the country, which plans to receive its first doses of the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine developed by Pfizer-BioNTech later this month.    While health care workers received their second jabs, people at the age of 70 and above are being administered their first shots.     The country's oldest citizens were vaccinated with their first jabs shortly after the first doses were administered to health care workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    On 12 February, people at the age of 65 or above will receive their first shots.    After completing the vaccination of senior citizens, the country will move to age-independent vaccination in the next phase of the plan. These people include soldiers, police officers, teachers and people working in sectors critical for daily life, from logistics to the food sector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:    During 13-14 February, inoculation is planned for members of the Cabinet, in a bid to set an example for the public. Vaccine skeptics and anti-vaxxers thrive on social media, looking to deter inoculation, though surveys show a large majority of people are willing to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214044314/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2nd-shot-at-hope-turkey-starts-new-round-of-covid-19-vaccines/news

A,C:     On 25 February, Health Minister Dr. Fahrettin Koca made a statement at the press conference held after the Coronavirus Scientific Committee meeting.    Minister Koca stated that 8 million doses of vaccination had been administered so far and that “We are approaching the end of the first phase in the vaccination plan."    The first phase included healthcare workers and people over age 65.     The second phase will include essential workers and people between the ages of 50 and 64.     As of 1 March, it is unclear whether the second phase has begun.    Currently, CoronaVac is the only vaccine being administered. The Health Ministry plans to diversify the vaccines by acquiring from other companies abroad, while trials continue for locally-made vaccines.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210309045419/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309052425/https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/turkey-passes-10-million-mark-in-covid-19-vaccinations/news    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309060458/https://covid19asi.saglik.gov.tr/TR-78296/asi-uygulanacak-grup-siralamasi.html

A:    Vaccines used: AstraZeneca    Taiwan’s Premier Su Tseng-chang received the AstraZeneca COVID-19 shot on Monday 22 March, having volunteered to be first in line to underscore government confidence in the vaccine’s safety as the island began its inoculation campaign. About 60,000 people are in line to get the first vaccinations and Taiwan is making sure its health workers are among the first to get it.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328015143/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/3/22/taiwan-kicks-off-covid-vaccination-campaign-with-astrazeneca-jab

The Central Epidemic Command Center of Taiwan announced in early April that COVID-19 vaccines will be 'offered to registered medical personnel, non-medical personnel at healthcare facilities, and other personnel included in the first group of vaccination program' from 6 April 2021.    https://archive.vn/Hfssu

Taiwan began to offer AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine on 6 April 2021 to Group 1 people listed in the COVID-19 vaccination program, including registered medical personnel, non-medical personnel at healthcare facilities and personnel at group quarantine facilities.    https://archive.vn/Hfssu

Taiwan began to offer AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine on 12 APR 2021 to 'personnel at the central and local governments and front-line workers at high risk of exposure, ... include flight crews of Taiwanese airlines, crewmembers on international merchant vessels, quarantine taxi drivers, and front-line workers who deal with quarantine-related matters at quarantine hotels.'    https://archive.vn/C8dOm

'On April 14, the Central Epidemic Command Center announced it would initially offer 10,000 self-paid COVID-19 vaccine doses to members of the public starting April 21. Related details are listed below.  1. Eligible persons: People who need to travel abroad for business, work, education, and medical treatment, and other humanitarian reasons or considerations.  2. Vaccination hospitals: A total of 31 hospitals with outpatient services in travel medicine that are designated for COVID-19 vaccination.  3. Self-paid vaccination is by appointment only.  4. The vaccine doses are distributed by the CECC to designated hospitals, and members of the public can't choose which brand of vaccine they wish to receive.  5. Members of the public who wish to receive self-paid vaccine doses must pay for the registration, diagnostic, and injection fees charged by the hospital for their vaccination; however, the cost of the vaccine itself will be waived.'    https://archive.vn/VcQN4

No availability, but an update on vaccination program:    The President of the Republic, Luis Lacalle Pou, reported that the first phase of the vaccination plan against COVID-19 will begin on March 1. On Friday 26, 192,000 doses of vaccines will arrive from the Sinovac laboratory for vaccinators, education workers, police, firefighters, military personnel and active INAU workers. 1,558,000 doses of Sinovac and weekly deliveries from Pfizer will arrive on March 15.  Accompanied by the Secretary of the Presidency, Álvaro Delgado, and the Minister of Public Health, Daniel Salinas, the president reported that 192,000 doses of the vaccines from the Sinovac laboratory will be received on Friday 26.  In March, as announced by President Lacalle Pou, Sinovac will complete the delivery of 1,558,000 doses, which will arrive on the 15th of that month. For its part, the Pfizer BioNTech laboratory will transfer 468,000 doses between March 8 and April 26. These vaccines will be inoculated to health personnel and older adults residing in institutions.  Once the priority groups have been covered, the vaccination plan will continue with the rest of the adults, the oldest first, until reaching the 18-year-olds.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210223003128/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/uruguay-contara-2-millones-dosis-vacunas-contra-covid-19-marzo

Vaccines still not available, but update regarding vaccination launch:    Next Monday, March 1, the first stage of the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19 begins.  it was determined that the priority group with which vaccination would begin would be made up of education workers, the INAU, police, military, firefighters and customs officials from the first line of control (airports, ports and dry borders). All provided that they are actively working and that they are under 60 years of age.  The first vaccine to arrive in our country on Thursday, February 25, was SINOVAC.  At the time of vaccination, the person will be asked to sign an agreement that indicates, on the one hand, that the vaccine they receive is free and not mandatory, on the other hand, that in the event of any claim to both the laboratory and the State, it must be made under the national jurisdiction. An electronic record of the vaccination will also be made, which will remain in the Vaccination Information System and may be requested from the health provider.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412161744/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/comienza-primera-etapa-del-plan-vacunacion-contra-covid-19

A (SinoVac):  All people under the age of 60 who actively perform tasks as education workers (which includes all pre-school, CAIF, primary, secondary and UTU areas), police, firefighters, INAU workers, military and customs officials of the first line of Control (airports, ports and dry borders). https://web.archive.org/web/20210412162716/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/apertura-agenda-vacunacion-covid-19  Uruguay, the last country in South America to receive delivery of coronavirus vaccines, started its inoculation campaign Monday with a focus on teachers, soldiers, police and firefighters. Some 90 vaccination centers countrywide opened their doors to give a first dose of the Chinese CoronaVac shot to some 140,000 essential workers. https://archive.vn/iDGnj

No evidence of a change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314151826/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias?field_publico_target_id=All&field_tematica_target_id=All&year=all&month=all&page=2

A (Sinovac):  All people who are qualified and expected to administer the Coronavac vaccine from the Sinovac Laboratory: firefighters, police, education workers and INAU, military (all active and under 60 years old), people on chronic dialysis, pre-transplant list and between the ages of 55 and 59, can be scheduled until today at 5:00 p.m. After this deadline, essential workers (firefighters, police, military, education workers and INAU) must be vaccinated according to the age group to which they belong. For people on chronic dialysis, the pre-transplant list and the 55 to 59 age group, the agenda will be opened again in a future instance that will be communicated in due course.  Then, starting at 6:00 p.m., as reported yesterday, health workers in priority areas will be able to schedule themselves to receive the first dose of the Pfizer/Biontech vaccine (expected to start vaccinations on March 12th): CTI, CTI Support Services, Out-of-hospital care, Emergency and Urgency Doors, Hospital stay, Surgical block, Swabs.  Note that although people on chronic dialysis, pre-transplant list and between the ages of 55 and 59 were eligible to receive Sinovac in the first round of vaccinations. However, this is a very specific population, therefore, this has still been coded as a 1G.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314144815/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/agenda-vacunacion

A and B: Health workers, persons deprived of liberty, and detention centre personnel.    On the night of Wednesday, March 10, the first 50,000 doses of the Covid-19 vaccine from the Pfizer / BioNTech laboratory arrived in Uruguay on a cargo flight of the German airline Lufthansa.  On Friday, March 12, at 8:00 a.m. The vaccination of people who perform tasks in the prioritized health areas began: swabs, care personnel at emergency and emergency doors, out-of-hospital care personnel, hospital admission, surgical block, ITC support service and ITC staff. Then it will be extended to the rest of the health personnel who, being very exposed to contracting and spreading the virus, was one of the first groups called to be vaccinated against Covid-19.    Additionally, people deprived of liberty and the personnel of detention facilities began getting vaccinated (starting with women's facilities and INISA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412165657/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/comenzo-inmunizacion-del-personal-salud  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322084002/https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-salud-publica/comunicacion/noticias/comunicado-sobre-plan-vacunacion-contra-covid-19

A, B and C:  On March 16, home vaccination of people who live, and work in residential homes (ELEPEM) began. However, as of 23 March 2021, Maine is only vaccinating key workers (PreK-12 teachers, school staff, etc) and elderly groups (age 50+). The state plans to expand vaccine eligibility to ages 16+ on 19 April 2021.   According to the Maine COVID-19 vaccine FAQ webpage:  "Maine is using an age-based approach to vaccination eligibility that reflect?scientific?data?indicating?that age is?among the strongest predictors of?whether an individual is likely to?get seriously ill and?die?from?COVID-19, even more so than risk factors?such as?underlying medical conditions." A press release from April 6 states that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has awarded funding to support local efforts to increase vaccine uptake by expanding COVID-19 vaccine programs and ensuring greater equity and access to vaccine by those disproportionately affected by SARS-CoV-2...  "The awards are part of $3 billion in funding that CDC has granted to 64 jurisdictions to bolster broad-based vaccine distribution, access, and administration efforts. The funding was made available by the American Rescue Plan and the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act and will provide critical support through CDC’s existing immunization cooperative agreements in communities around the country."    Nearly 80 percent of Pre-K-12 teachers, school staff, and childcare workers received at least their first shot of COVID-19 vaccine by the end of March, according to the CDC’s latest estimates. Based on state-level coding within this dataset, all states are providing vaccinations to at least 3 groups at this time, and many are expanding eligibility to anyone 16 years old or older.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414010026/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0407-covid-19-vaccine-programs.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414010259/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0406-teachers-staff-vaccine.html

On April 13 the CDC and FDA released a joint statement on the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine, which is reported to have caused blood clots in six  individuals who received the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine. The statement says that as of April 12, more than 6.8 million doses of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen ) vaccine have been administered in the U.S.     "CDC will convene a meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) on Wednesday to further review these cases and assess their potential significance. FDA will review that analysis as it also investigates these cases. Until that process is complete, we are recommending a pause in the use of this vaccine out of an abundance of caution. This is important, in part, to ensure that the health care provider community is aware of the potential for these adverse events and can plan for proper recognition and management due to the unique treatment required with this type of blood clot."    Given this news, it is likely that states will pause the use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine and will continue to use Pfizer and Moderna vaccines; this may delay timelines for vaccine eligibility to wider groups of people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414011900/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0413-JJ-vaccine.html

Has the government of Vietnam approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? [Yes]  Vietnam has approved the COVID-19 vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford for use in urgent situations.  According to Vietnam’s Ministry of Health, it is expected that the Oxford- Astra Zeneca vaccine will be available in the first quarter of 2021.

"Vietnam would receive around five million Covid-19 vaccine doses by the end of February, Deputy Health Minister Truong Quoc Cuong said at a meeting Tuesday.  They include about 4.9 million vaccine doses provided via Covax. About 117,000 other doses would be imported... by the end of February.    With the vaccine doses, five million people will receive the first shots, and three months later the second shots would be administered. Around two to five million people on the frontline of the coronavirus fight would be prioritized to get the vaccine."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215195049/https://vietreader.com/news/33728-vietnam-to-receive-five-million-covid-19-vaccine-doses-within-this-month.html

"Vietnam's government said on Tuesday health workers, diplomats and military personnel would be among the first to be vaccinated against COVID-19 when the country starts its inoculation programme next month.  ...  In the first quarter of 2021, Vietnam aims to inoculate 500,000 medical staff and 116,000 others directly involved in the fight against the pandemic, the government said in a statement.  ...  In the second quarter, Vietnam plans to vaccinate 1.8 million more people, including 9,200 customs officials, 4,080 diplomats, 1.03 million military personnel, 304,000 police officers and 550,000 teachers, the government said."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301063117/https://www.msn.com/en-au/lifestyle/wellbeing/vietnam-details-priorities-for-first-phase-of-covid-19-vaccinations/ar-BB1dVeLA?oci_d=mailsignout

A: (AstraZeneca) On March 8, Vietnam begin vaccinations for front-line workers and health care staff in 12 provinces / cities: Hai Duong, Hanoi, Hung Yen, Bac Ninh, Bac Giang, Hai Phong, and Ho Chi Minh City. Ho Chi Minh City, Gia Lai, Long An, Da Nang, Hoa Binh and Khanh Hoa.  From March 8 to 15, a total of 15,865 people were vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316031826/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/vi/web/guest/-/6847426-2069

A (AstraZeneca): According to data of the National Immunization Program in Vietnam, up to 16:00 on March 18, 2021, Vietnam has implemented AstraZeneca vaccination for 27,546 people. All of them are medical staff and staff directly treating patients with COVID-19, medical staff performing tasks such as taking samples, testing, tracing, members of COVID- 19 communities and the local epidemic control steering committee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323005658/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/vi/web/guest/-/6847912-114

Ministry of Health and related ministries and agencies currently the reviewing the implementation of a vaccine passport for COVID-19 allowing immunization history for both doses to be tracked for themselves and for their families. Individuals will be issued a certificate of injection to be updated by a healthcare worker. People who come for vaccination will need to bring ID card / citizenship ID or health insurance card to verify their eligibility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323005658/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/vi/web/guest/-/6847912-114

A (AstraZeneca): As of March 30, a total of 48,256 health workers who are directly treating COVID-19 patients have been vaccinated in 19 provinces/cities. These health workers encompasses work such as sampling, testing, tracing, members of the community COVID-19 groups and the Steering Committee for epidemic prevention.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222015/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/en/web/guest/-/6847426-2254  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222101/http://news.chinhphu.vn/Home/Viet-Nam-To-Begin-COVID19-Vaccination-Next-Monday/20213/43138.vgp  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405161744/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

A (AstraZeneca): Frontline health workers continue to be vaccinated. These include medical staff and staff directly treating patients with COVID-19, medical staff performing tasks such as sampling, testing, tracing, members of the COVID-19 plus groups. and the Steering Committee for epidemic prevention in localities.  On April 1, COVAX's first batch of 811,200 doses arrived in Vietnam. A total of 4.1 million doses of vaccine expected to be available in Vietnam by the end of May 2021. Vietnam will reach the target of providing vaccines to 20% of the population by the end of 2021  As of April 12, the total number of vaccinated individuals is 58,418.    On April 6, the Ministry of Health has issued a document to expedite 63 provinces and cities to make a list of 10 priority groups for COVID-19 vaccination.  1. The front-line forces of anti-epidemic prevention include:  - People working in medical establishments.  - Participants in epidemic prevention (members of the Steering Committee for epidemic prevention and control at all levels, people working in isolated areas, in charge of tracking, epidemiological investigation, community-based COVID team, volunteers , reporter...).  - Military force (local forces involved in epidemic prevention).  - Police force (local forces involved in epidemic prevention).  2. Vietnamese diplomatic staff and officers and their relatives sent for term work; officials directly participated in welcoming Government delegations and welcoming Vietnamese from abroad; Diplomatic Corps and UN system organizations in Vietnam.  3. Customs staff, immigration officer.  4. Essential service providers: aviation, transport, and tourism; providing electricity and water services ...  5. Teachers, people working at educational and training establishments; People working at agencies and administrative units often contact with many people.  6. People with chronic diseases.  7. People over 65 years old.  8. People living in epidemic areas.  9. The poor, social policy beneficiaries.  10. Persons sent by competent state agencies to work abroad, study or work abroad.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412231904/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/en/web/guest/-/6847426-2316  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412232651/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/en/web/guest/-/6847426-2320  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412232219/https://ncov.moh.gov.vn/en/web/guest/-/6847426-2293

Lusaka that 13 vaccines that have been proven to be effective will be available, noting that only COVAX and astrazeneca will be administered to citizens by government.
